book.name: Mark
book.info: The words spoken in [link]13:2[/link] seem to indicate that this book was written before the destruction of the holy temple. Perhaps it was written between A.D. 67 and 70, after the death of the apostle Paul.

Frequent explanations of Jewish names, customs, and festivals in this book ([link]3:17[/link]; [link]5:41[/link]; [link]7:3[/link], [link]11[/link]; [link]14:12[/link]; [link]15:42[/link]) prove that it was written to the Gentiles, specifically the Romans.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]beginning of the [note]2[/note]gospel of [note]3[/note]Jesus Christ, [note]4[/note]the [xref]a[/xref]Son of God,
verse.note: The writer of this Gospel was Mark, also called John ([link]Acts 12:25[/link]), the son of one of the Marys (who was close to the apostle Peter in the church at Jerusalem — [link]Acts 12:12[/link]) and the cousin of Barnabas ([link]Col. 4:10[/link]). He accompanied Barnabas and Saul in their ministry ([link]Acts 12:25[/link]) and joined Paul in the first journey of his ministry to the Gentiles; but he left Paul and turned back at Perga ([link]Acts 13:13[/link]). Because of his turning back, Paul refused to take him on his second journey. At that time Barnabas separated himself from Paul, and Mark then joined Barnabas in his work ([link]Acts 15:36-40[/link]). However, Mark was close to Paul in Paul's later years ([link]Col. 4:10[/link]; [link]Philem. 24[/link]) and was useful to him for his ministry until Paul's martyrdom ([link]2 Tim. 4:11[/link]). He was close to Peter and was probably with him continually, as seen in the fact that Peter considered him his son ([link]1 Pet. 5:13[/link]). From the early days of the church his Gospel has been considered a written account of the oral presentation of Peter, who accompanied the Savior in His gospel service from its beginning ([link]vv. 16-18[/link]) to its end ([link]14:54[/link], [link]66-72[/link]). Mark's record is according to historical sequence and gives more details concerning the historical facts than the other Gospels. The entire Gospel is summarized in Peter's word in [link]Acts 10:36-42[/link].[br][br]John presents the God-Savior, emphasizing the Savior's deity in His humanity. Matthew presents the King-Savior; Mark, the Slave-Savior; and Luke, the Man-Savior. Matthew, Mark, and Luke are synoptic in portraying the Savior's humanity in different aspects, with His deity. Since Mark presents the Savior as a slave, he does not tell His genealogy and status, because the ancestry of a slave is not worthy of note. Furthermore, in contrast to Matthew, who presents to us the Savior's marvelous teachings and parables concerning the heavenly kingdom, and John, who presents His profound revelations of divine truths, Mark's intention is not to impress us with the Slave's wonderful words but with His excellent deeds in His gospel service. Mark's Gospel provides more detail than the other Gospels in order to portray the Slave-Savior's diligence, faithfulness, and other virtues in the saving service He rendered to sinners for God. In Mark's Gospel are the fulfillment of the prophecies in [link]Isa. 42:1-4[/link], [link]6-7[/link]; [link]49:5-7[/link]; [link]50:4-7[/link]; [link]52:13-53:12[/link] concerning Christ as the Slave of Jehovah, and the details of the teaching in [link]Phil. 2:5-11[/link] regarding Christ as the Slave of God. His diligence in labor, His need of food and rest ([link]3:20-21[/link]; [link]6:31[/link]), His anger ([link]3:5[/link]), His groaning ([link]7:34[/link]), and His affection ([link]10:21[/link]) display beautifully His humanity in its virtue and perfection, while His lordship ([link]2:28[/link]), His omniscience ([link]2:8[/link]), His miraculous power, and His authority to cast out demons ([link]v. 27[/link]; [link]3:15[/link]), to forgive sins ([link]2:7[/link], [link]10[/link]), and to silence the wind and the sea ([link]4:39[/link]) manifest in full His deity in its glory and honor. What a Slave of God! How lovely and admirable! Such a Slave served sinners as their Slave-Savior, with His life as their ransom ([link]10:45[/link]), for the fulfillment of the eternal purpose of God, whose Slave He was.

I.e., glad tidings, good news ([link]Rom. 10:15[/link]). The gospel is the service (ministry) of the Slave-Savior as a Slave of God serving His people. Matthew begins with the kingly generations of Christ the King ([link]Matt. 1:1-17[/link]); Luke, with a human genealogy of Jesus the man ([link]Luke 3:23-38[/link]); and John, with the eternal origin of the Son of God ([link]John 1:1-2[/link]); whereas Mark begins not with the origin of His person but with the beginning of the gospel, the service of Jesus as a lowly Slave of God ([link]Phil. 2:7[/link]; [link]Matt. 20:27-28[/link]). As a rule, the service, not the person, of a slave is notable. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link].

This Gospel is a biography of the Slave-Savior, who was God incarnated as a Slave to save sinners. In this compound title, [i]Jesus Christ[/i] denotes His humanity and [i]the Son of God,[/i] His deity, both of which were adequately expressed by His human virtues and divine attributes in His ministry and move for His gospel service, as recorded in this Gospel.
Some MSS omit, the Son of God.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Even as it is written in Isaiah the prophet: [xref]a[/xref]"Behold, [note]2[/note]I send My [note]3[/note]messenger before [note]4[/note]Your face, who will [note]5[/note]prepare Your way,
verse.note: The beginning of the gospel of the Slave-Savior was even as it is written in Isaiah concerning the ministry of John the Baptist. This indicates that John's preaching of the baptism of repentance was also a part of the gospel of Jesus Christ. It terminated the dispensation of law and replaced it with the dispensation of grace. Hence, the dispensation of grace began with the ministry of John, before the ministry of the Slave-Savior.
Jehovah of hosts ([link]Mal. 3:1[/link]).
The same Greek word as for [i]angel.[/i] So in [link]Rev. 1:20[/link].
Jesus Christ's.
Lit., furnish. The preaching of the baptism of repentance ([link]v. 4[/link]) paved the way for the Slave-Savior to come to sinners ([link]Luke 1:76[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]A [note]1[/note]voice of one crying in the [note]2[/note]wilderness: [note]3[/note]Prepare the way of the Lord; make straight His paths."
verse.note: The ministry of the gospel of the Slave-Savior began with only a voice, not with a great movement.

The preaching of the gospel of the Slave-Savior began not in any center of civilization but in the wilderness, beyond the influence of human culture. See notes [link book="Matt." chapter="3"]3[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].

Lit., make ready. To prepare the way of the Lord is to change people's mind, turning their mind toward the Slave-Savior, and to make their heart right, straightening every part of their heart through repentance, that the Slave-Savior may enter into them to be their life and take possession of them ([link]Luke 1:17[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]John [note]1[/note]came baptizing in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]wilderness and preaching a [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]baptism of [xref]d[/xref]repentance [note]4[/note]for [xref]e[/xref]forgiveness of sins.
verse.note: I.e., appeared.

John was born a priest ([link]Luke 1:8-13[/link], [link]57-63[/link]); hence, he should have lived a priestly life in the temple, doing the priestly service. But he came to the wilderness and preached the gospel. This indicates that the age of the priesthood, in which sacrifices were offered to God, had been replaced by the age of the gospel, in which sinners are brought to God that God may gain sinners and that sinners may gain God.

Repentance is to change one's mind, turning it to the Slave-Savior, and baptism is to bury the repenting people, terminating them that the Slave-Savior may germinate them by regeneration ([link]John 3:3[/link], [link]5-6[/link]).
Or, unto. Repentance with baptism is for, and results in, forgiveness of sins, that the obstacle of man's fall may be removed and man may be reconciled to God.

verse.text: And all the [xref]a[/xref]region of [note]1[/note]Judea went out to him, and all the [i]people[/i] of Jerusalem; and they were [note]2[/note]baptized by him in the [note]3[/note]Jordan River, as they [xref]b[/xref]confessed their sins.
verse.note: A region with the holy city, the holy temple, and high culture; hence, a region of honor.

When people repented through his preaching, John immersed them into the death water to bury them, to terminate them, thus preparing them to be raised up by the Slave-Savior, who germinated them with the Holy Spirit through the confession of their sins. See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].
See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].

verse.text: And John was [note]1[/note]clothed in camel's [xref]a[/xref]hair and [i]had[/i] a leather girdle around his loins, and he ate [xref]b[/xref]locusts and wild [xref]c[/xref]honey.
verse.note: The way John lived signifies that his living and work were altogether in a new dispensation and were not according to the way of the old religion, culture, and tradition. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].

verse.text: And he preached, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]He who is stronger than I comes after me, the thong of whose sandals I am not worthy to stoop down and untie.
verse.note: Although John preached a baptism of repentance, the goal of his ministry was a wonderful person, Jesus Christ, the Son of God. He did not make himself the center of his ministry, as a magnet attracting others to himself. He realized that he was only a messenger sent by Jehovah of hosts to bring people to His Son, Jesus Christ, and to exalt Him as the goal of his ministry.

verse.text: I have baptized you in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]water, but He Himself will baptize you in the Holy [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Spirit.
verse.note: Water signifies death and burial for the termination of the repenting people; the Holy Spirit is the Spirit of life and resurrection for the germination of the terminated people. The former was a sign of John's ministry of repentance; the latter, a sign of the Slave-Savior's ministry of life. John buried the repenting people in the death water; the Slave-Savior raised them up that they might be regenerated in the Spirit of His resurrection life. The death water, pointing to and signifying the all-inclusive death of Christ, into which His believers are baptized ([link]Rom. 6:3[/link]), buried not only the baptized people but also their sins, the world, and their past life and history (just as the Red Sea buried Pharaoh and the Egyptian army for the children of Israel — [link]Exo. 14:26-28[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 10:2[/link]) and separated them from the God-forsaking world and its corruption (just as the flood did for Noah and his family — [link]1 Pet. 3:20-21[/link]). The Holy Spirit, into whom the Slave-Savior baptized those who believed in Him, is the Spirit of Christ and the Spirit of God ([link]Rom. 8:9[/link]). Hence, to be baptized in the Holy Spirit is to be baptized into Christ ([link]Gal. 3:27[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:3[/link]), into the Triune God ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]), and even into the Body of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]), which is joined to Christ in the one Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]). It is through baptism in such a water and in such a Spirit that the believers in Christ are regenerated into the kingdom of God ([link]John 3:3[/link], [link]5[/link], and note [link]5[sup]2[/sup][/link]), into the realm of the divine life and the divine rule, that they may live by the eternal life of God in His eternal kingdom.

verse.text: And in those days Jesus [xref]a[/xref]came from [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Nazareth of Galilee and was [note]2[/note]baptized [note]3[/note]in the Jordan by John.
verse.note: Galilee was called "Galilee of the Gentiles" and was a region without honor, hence, a despised region ([link]John 7:52[/link]; see note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link]), and Nazareth was a despised city of that despised region ([link]John 1:46[/link]). The lowly Slave of God grew up and came out from that source.

As a Slave of God, the Slave-Savior too was baptized, signifying that He was willing to serve God and that He would serve not in man's natural way but through death and resurrection (see notes [link book="Matt." chapter="3"]13[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link]). Such a baptism was the initiation of His service.
Lit., into.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]immediately, coming up out of the water, He saw the [note]2[/note]heavens being [xref]b[/xref]parted and the [xref]c[/xref]Spirit as a [note]3[/note]dove descending upon Him[note]4[/note].
verse.note: Mark's record of a Slave reflects not the splendor of the status of this Slave's person but the diligence of His service. The word [i]immediately[/i] is used in his record forty-two times, and one more time in alternate MSS.

The heavens being opened to the Slave-Savior signifies that His willing offering of Himself as a Slave to God was well accepted by God, and the Spirit's descending as a dove upon Him signifies that God anointed Him with the Spirit for His service to Him ([link]Luke 4:18-19[/link]).
See note [link]16[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].
Some MSS add, and remaining.

verse.text: And a [xref]a[/xref]voice came out of the heavens: [note]1[/note]You are My Son, the [xref]b[/xref]Beloved; in You I have found My [xref]c[/xref]delight.
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately the Spirit [note]1[/note]thrust Him out into the [xref]b[/xref]wilderness.
verse.note: After God's acceptance and anointing, the first thing the Spirit did with this Slave of God was to thrust Him into a test to prove His integrity.

verse.text: And He was in the wilderness [note]1[/note]forty days, being [xref]a[/xref]tempted by [note]2[/note]Satan; and He was with the wild animals, and the [xref]b[/xref]angels ministered to Him.
verse.note: A time of testing and suffering ([link]Deut. 9:9[/link], [link]18[/link]; [link]1 Kings 19:8[/link]).

Satan, the enemy of God, was used for the testing and proving of God's Slave. The animals of the earth, in a negative sense, and the angels from heaven, in a positive sense, also were used for this test.

verse.text: And after John was [xref]a[/xref]delivered up, Jesus came into [note]1[/note]Galilee, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]proclaiming the [xref]c[/xref]gospel [note]3[/note]of God,
verse.note: John's imprisonment was a sign of the rejection of the gospel, especially in the region of honor. Hence, the Slave-Savior left that region and returned to the despised region for His service of the gospel. See notes [link book="Matt." chapter="4"]12[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].[br][br]The gospel service was initiated in Judea, the region of honor, by the ministry of the Slave-Savior's forerunner ([link]vv. 1-11[/link]); but it was continued in Galilee, the despised region, by the ministry of the Slave-Savior for a period of about three years ([link]v. 14-9:50[/link]). In contrast to John's record in his Gospel ([link]John 1:29-42[/link]; [link]2:13-3:36[/link]; [link]5:1-47[/link]; [link]7:10-11:57[/link]), Mark recorded nothing of the Slave-Savior's ministry in Jerusalem and Judea during that period of time. Mark recorded only the Lord's leaving of Galilee to go to Jerusalem for the last time ([link]10:1[/link]) to accomplish His redemptive work. Then the gospel service was continued by His ministry on the way to Jerusalem and in Jerusalem and its vicinity ([link]10:1-14:42[/link]). It was concluded with His redeeming death, His life-imparting resurrection, His ascension for exaltation, and the continuation of His gospel service, carried out by His disciples' preaching to all the creation ([link]14:43-16:20[/link]).

The Slave-Savior's proclaiming was to announce God's glad tidings to the miserable people in bondage; His teaching ([link]vv. 21-22[/link]) was to enlighten the ignorant ones in darkness with the divine light of the truth. His proclaiming implied teaching, and His teaching implied proclaiming ([link]Matt. 4:23[/link]). This was the first thing He did in His ministry, and it was the all-embracing structure of His evangelistic service ([link]vv. 38-39[/link]; [link]3:14[/link]; [link]6:12[/link]; [link]14:9[/link]; [link]16:15[/link], [link]20[/link]).
Some MSS add, of the kingdom. The gospel of Jesus Christ ([link]v. 1[/link]) is the gospel of God ([link]Rom. 1:1[/link]) and the gospel of the kingdom of God (cf. [link]Matt. 4:23[/link]).

verse.text: And saying, The time is [xref]a[/xref]fulfilled and the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God has drawn near. [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Repent and [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]believe in the [note]4[/note]gospel.
verse.note: The kingdom of God is the ruling, the reigning, of God with all its blessing and enjoyment. It is the goal of the gospel of God and of Jesus Christ (see notes [link chapter="4"]3[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]26[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]). To enter into this kingdom, people need to repent of their sins and believe in the gospel that their sins may be forgiven and that they may be regenerated by God to have the divine life, which matches the divine nature of this kingdom ([link]John 3:3[/link], [link]5[/link]). All the believers in Christ can share the kingdom in the church age for their enjoyment of God in His righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]). This kingdom will become the kingdom of Christ and of God for the overcoming believers to inherit and enjoy in the coming kingdom age ([link]1 Cor. 6:9-10[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:21[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:5[/link]) that they may reign with Christ a thousand years ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]). Then, as the eternal kingdom it will be an eternal blessing of God's eternal life for all God's redeemed to enjoy in the new heaven and new earth for eternity ([link]Rev. 21:1-4[/link]; [link]22:1-5[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]17[/link]). It was such a kingdom of God that had drawn near and into which the gospel of the Slave-Savior would bring His believers. For this kingdom the Slave-Savior told people to repent and believe in the gospel. See notes [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in John 3[/link], [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link], and [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

The Greek word means [i]have a change of mind.[/i] To repent is to have a change of mind with regret for the past and a turn for the future. On the negative side, to repent before God is not only to repent of sins and wrongdoings but also to repent of the world and its corruption, which usurp and corrupt people whom God created for Himself, and to repent of our God-forsaking life in the past. On the positive side, it is to turn to God in every way and in everything for the fulfillment of His purpose in creating man. It is a "repentance unto God," and is to "repent and turn to God" ([link]Acts 20:21[/link]; [link]26:20[/link]). See notes [link book="Matt." chapter="3"]2[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].

Repentance is mainly in the mind; believing is mainly in the heart ([link]Rom. 10:9[/link]). To believe in is to believe into the things in which we believe and to receive into us the things in which we believe. To believe in the gospel is mainly to believe in the Slave-Savior ([link]Acts 16:31[/link]), and to believe in Him is to believe into Him ([link]John 3:15-16[/link]) and to receive Him into us ([link]John 1:12[/link]) that we may be organically united with Him. Such a faith in Christ ([link]Gal. 3:22[/link]) is given to us by God through our hearing of the word of the truth of the gospel ([link]Rom. 10:17[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:13[/link]). This faith brings us into all the blessings of the gospel ([link]Gal. 3:14[/link]). Hence, it is precious to us ([link]2 Pet. 1:1[/link]). Such a precious faith must be preceded by repentance. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

This is the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God ([link]v. 1[/link]), the gospel of God, and the gospel of the kingdom of God. Jesus Christ, the Son of God, with all the processes He passed through (such as incarnation, crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension) and all the redemptive work He accomplished, is the content of the gospel ([link]Rom. 1:2-4[/link]; [link]Luke 2:10-11[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:1-4[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 2:8[/link]). Hence, the gospel is of Him. The gospel was planned, promised, and accomplished by God ([link]Eph. 1:8-9[/link]; [link]Acts 2:23[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Acts 3:15[/link]), and it is the power of God unto salvation to all the believers ([link]Rom. 1:16[/link]) that they may be reconciled to God ([link]2 Cor. 5:19[/link]) and regenerated by Him ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]) to be His children ([link]John 1:12-13[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:16[/link]) and to enjoy all His riches and blessings as their inheritance ([link]Eph. 1:14[/link]). Hence, it is the gospel of God. It brings the believers into the realm of the divine ruling that they may participate in the blessings of the divine life in the divine kingdom ([link]1 Thes. 2:12[/link]). Hence, it is also the gospel of the kingdom of God. Thus, its full contents are the same as those of the New Testament with all its bequests. When we believe in this gospel, we inherit the Triune God with His redemption, His salvation, and His divine life with its riches as our eternal portion.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]passing beside the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Sea of Galilee, He saw [xref]c[/xref]Simon and Andrew, Simon's brother, [note]2[/note]casting a [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]net in the sea, for they were fishermen.
verse.note: See note [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].
See note [link]18[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].
Referring to an arc-shaped net.

verse.text: And Jesus said to them, Come after Me, and I will cause you to become fishers of men.
And [xref]a[/xref]immediately leaving the nets, they [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]followed Him.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].

verse.text: And going on a little, He saw James the [i]son[/i] of Zebedee and [xref]a[/xref]John his brother, who also [i]were[/i] in their boat, [note]1[/note]mending the nets.
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately He [xref]b[/xref]called them, and leaving their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired servants, they [note]1[/note]went after Him.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].

verse.text: And they [xref]a[/xref]went into [xref]b[/xref]Capernaum, and [xref]c[/xref]immediately, on the Sabbath, He entered into the [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]synagogue and [note]2[/note]taught.
verse.note: A synagogue is a meeting place where the Jews read and learn the Holy Scriptures ([link]Luke 4:16-17[/link]; [link]Acts 13:14-15[/link]).

Man's fall into sin broke his fellowship with God, making all men ignorant of the knowledge of God. Such ignorance issued first in darkness and then in death. The Slave-Savior, as the light of the world ([link]John 8:12[/link]; [link]9:5[/link]), came as a great light to Galilee, the land of darkness, to shine on the people who were sitting in the shadow of death ([link]Matt. 4:12-16[/link]). His teaching released the word of light to enlighten those in the darkness of death that they might receive the light of life ([link]John 1:4[/link]). The second thing that the Slave of God did in His service as the Slave-Savior to fallen men was to carry out such teaching ([link]2:13[/link]; [link]4:1[/link]; [link]6:2[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]30[/link], [link]34[/link]; [link]10:1[/link]; [link]11:17[/link]; [link]12:35[/link]; [link]14:49[/link]) to bring people out of the satanic darkness into the divine light ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]).

verse.text: And they were [xref]a[/xref]astounded at His [xref]b[/xref]teaching, for He taught them as One having [note]1[/note]authority and not like the scribes.
verse.note: The self-appointed scribes, who by themselves were teaching vain knowledge, had no authority and no power, but this God-authorized Slave, who by God was teaching realities, had not only spiritual power to subdue people but also divine authority to subject people to the divine ruling.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately, there was in their synagogue a man with an unclean [note]1[/note]spirit, and he cried out, saying,
verse.note: Not a fallen angel but a demon ([link]vv. 32[/link], [link]34[/link], [link]39[/link]; [link]Luke 4:33[/link]), a disembodied spirit of one of the living creatures who lived in the preadamic age and were judged by God when they joined Satan's rebellion (see [i]Life-study of Genesis,[/i] Message Two). The fallen angels work with Satan in the air ([link]Eph. 2:2[/link]; [link]6:11-12[/link]), and these unclean spirits, the demons, move with him on the earth. Both act evilly upon man for the kingdom of Satan. The demons' possession of people signifies Satan's usurpation of man, whom God created for His purpose. The third thing the Slave-Savior, who came to destroy the works of Satan ([link]1 John 3:8[/link]), did as a part of His service to God was to cast out these demons from the possessed people ([link]vv. 34[/link], [link]39[/link]; [link]3:15[/link]; [link]6:7[/link], [link]13[/link]; [link]16:17[/link]) that they might be delivered from Satan's bondage ([link]Luke 13:16[/link]), out of Satan's authority of darkness ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]; [link]Col. 1:13[/link]), into God's kingdom ([link]v. 15[/link]). Five cases are recorded in this Gospel to illustrate this ([link]vv. 23-27[/link]; [link]5:2-20[/link]; [link]7:25-30[/link]; [link]9:17-27[/link]; [link]16:9[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]What have we to [xref]a[/xref]do with You, Jesus, [xref]b[/xref]Nazarene? Have You come to destroy us? I [xref]c[/xref]know who You are — the [xref]d[/xref]Holy One of God.
verse.note: Lit., What to us and to You? (a Hebrew idiom).

verse.text: And Jesus [xref]a[/xref]rebuked him, saying, Be [xref]b[/xref]quiet and come out of him!
And the [xref]a[/xref]unclean spirit, [xref]b[/xref]convulsing him and shouting with a [xref]c[/xref]loud voice, came out of him.

And they were all [xref]a[/xref]amazed, so that they discussed among themselves, saying, What is this? A [xref]b[/xref]new teaching! With [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]authority He orders even the unclean spirits, and they [xref]d[/xref]obey Him.
verse.note: It was not power but authority that cast out the demon. For His service the Slave-Savior had divine authority not only to teach people ([link]v. 22[/link]) but also to cast out demons.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately the report concerning Him went out everywhere into all the surrounding region of Galilee.
And immediately, going out of the synagogue, they came into the [xref]a[/xref]house of Simon and Andrew with James and John.
And Simon's [xref]a[/xref]mother-in-law was lying down with a [note]1[/note]fever, and [xref]b[/xref]immediately they told Him about her.
verse.note: This may signify a person's unbridled temper, which is abnormal and intemperate.

verse.text: And He came to [i]her[/i] and raised her up, [xref]a[/xref]holding her hand, and the fever [note]1[/note]left her, and she [note]2[/note]served them.
verse.note: Sickness issues from sin and is a sign of man's abnormal condition before God because of sin. The fourth thing the Slave-Savior did to rescue the sinners, as another part of His gospel service, was to heal their sick condition physically and spiritually and restore them to normality ([link]v. 34[/link]; [link]3:10[/link]; [link]6:5[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]56[/link]) that they might serve Him. Nine cases are recorded in this Gospel to illustrate such healing ([link]vv. 30-31[/link], [link]40-45[/link]; [link]2:3-12[/link]; [link]3:1-5[/link]; [link]5:22-43[/link]; [link]7:32-37[/link]; [link]8:22-26[/link]; [link]10:46-52[/link]).
First she was healed, then she served.

verse.text: And when evening fell and the sun had set, they brought to Him all those who were ill and those who were demon-possessed.
And the whole city was [xref]a[/xref]gathered together at the door.

And He [note]1[/note]healed many who were ill with various [xref]a[/xref]diseases, and He [note]2[/note]cast out many demons and did [xref]b[/xref]not allow the demons to speak, because [note]3[/note]they [xref]c[/xref]knew Him.
verse.note: See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup][/link].
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup][/link]. So in [link]v. 39[/link].
Some MSS read, they knew Him to be Christ.

verse.text: And rising very [xref]a[/xref]early in the morning, [i]while it was still[/i] night, He went out and went away to a deserted place, and there He [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]prayed.
verse.note: To fellowship with God, seeking God's will and pleasure for His gospel service. The Slave-Savior performed the evangelistic service not by Himself, independent of God and according to His own will, but according to God's will and pleasure by being one with God to fulfill His purpose (see note [link]38[sup]2[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: And Simon and those with him hunted for Him,
And they found Him and said to Him, All are seeking You.

And He said to them, Let us go [xref]a[/xref]elsewhere into the nearby towns that I may [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]preach there also, because for [note]2[/note]this [i]purpose[/i] I [xref]c[/xref]came out.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]2[/sup][/link].

As the Slave of God, the Slave-Savior served God in His gospel to carry out not His own will or the people's proposal but the will of God, who had sent Him ([link]John 6:38[/link]; [link]4:34[/link]).

verse.text: And He went preaching in their [xref]a[/xref]synagogues in the whole of Galilee and casting out the demons.
And a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]leper came to Him, entreating Him and [xref]b[/xref]falling on his knees and saying to Him, If You are willing, You can [xref]c[/xref]cleanse me.
verse.note: A leper portrays a typical sinner. Leprosy is the most contaminating and damaging disease, much more serious than a fever ([link]v. 30[/link]), causing its victim to be isolated from God and from men (see notes [link book="Matt." chapter="8"]2[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 8[/link]). The cleansing of the leper signifies the recovering of the sinner to the fellowship with God and with men. This was the consummating part of the Slave-Savior's gospel service according to the record of this chapter.[br][br]The Slave-Savior's gospel service to God comprised (1) preaching ([link]vv. 14-15[/link], [link]38-39[/link]) to announce the glad tidings to the miserable people in bondage; (2) teaching ([link]vv. 21-22[/link]) to enlighten the ignorant ones in darkness with the divine light of the truth; (3) casting out demons ([link]vv. 25-26[/link]) to annihilate Satan's usurpation of man; (4) healing man's sick condition ([link]vv. 30-31[/link]) that man might serve the Slave-Savior; and (5) cleansing the leper ([link]vv. 41-42[/link]) to recover the sinner to the fellowship with God and with men. What a wonderful and excellent work!

verse.text: And He was moved with [note]1[/note]compassion, and [note]2[/note]stretching out His hand, He touched him and said to him, I am [note]1[/note]willing; be [note]3[/note]cleansed!
verse.note: The Slave-Savior's compassion and willingness, issuing from His love, were dear and precious to the hopeless leper.
Showing His sympathy and intimacy toward the miserable leper, whom no one dared to touch.

Not only healed (see note [link]31[sup]1[/sup][/link]) but cleansed. Like other diseases, leprosy requires healing; like sin ([link]1 John 1:7[/link]), it also requires cleansing because of its filthy and contaminating nature.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately the leprosy left him, and he was [xref]b[/xref]cleansed.
And sternly [xref]a[/xref]charging him, immediately He thrust him out,

And said to him, See that you [note]1[/note]say nothing to anyone; but go, show yourself to the [xref]a[/xref]priest and offer for your cleansing the things which Moses commanded, for a testimony to them.
verse.note: Such a charge, given throughout the record of the Slave-Savior's evangelistic service, is quite striking ([link]5:43[/link]; [link]7:36[/link]; [link]9:9[/link]). It is similar to what was prophesied in [link]Isa. 42:2[/link] concerning His quiet character. He wanted His work to be done within the limits of a move that was absolutely according to God's purpose and that was not promoted by man's excitement and propaganda. See note [link book="Mark"]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: But he went out and began to [xref]a[/xref]proclaim [i]it[/i] much and to spread the [note]1[/note]matter abroad, so that He could [note]2[/note]no longer enter openly into a city, but He stayed outside in [xref]b[/xref]deserted places. And they [xref]c[/xref]came to Him from everywhere.
verse.note: Lit., word.
Man's activity, which is according to the natural concept, frustrates the Slave-Savior's service, which is according to God's purpose.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]He entered again into [xref]a[/xref]Capernaum after [i]a few[/i] days, and it was heard that He was [note]2[/note]at home.
verse.note: The five incidents vividly recorded in [link]2:1-3:6[/link] form one particular group, showing how the Slave-Savior as the Slave of God carried out His gospel service to care for the needs of fallen people, who had been captured by Satan and carried away from God and the enjoyment of God, that they might be rescued from their captivity and might be brought back to God as their enjoyment.[br][br](1) As God with divine authority, He forgave the sins of the victim of sickness that He might release him from Satan's oppression ([link]Acts 10:38[/link]) and restore him to God. The scribes considered this to be against the theology of their religion ([link]vv. 1-12[/link]).[br][br](2) As a Physician to the sick and miserable people, He feasted with the tax collectors, who were disloyal and unfaithful to their race, and with sinners, who were despised and isolated from society, that they might taste the mercy of God and be recovered to the enjoyment of God. This was condemned by the self-righteous yet merciless scribes of the Pharisees ([link]vv. 13-17[/link]).[br][br](3) As a Bridegroom with the sons of the bridechamber, He caused His followers to be merry and happy without fasting. Thus He annulled the practice of the disciples of John (the new religionists) and the Pharisees (the old religionists) so that His followers could be delivered from the practices of their religion into the enjoyment of God's Christ as their Bridegroom, with His righteousness as their outer clothing and His life as their inner wine in God's New Testament economy ([link]vv. 18-22[/link]).[br][br](4) He allowed His followers to pick the ears of grain in the grainfields on the Sabbath so that they could satisfy their hunger. Thus, apparently they broke God's commandment concerning the Sabbath, but actually they pleased God because the hunger of Christ's followers was satisfied through Him, as the hunger of David and his followers had been satisfied with the bread of the Presence in the house of God. This indicates that in God's New Testament economy, it is a matter not of keeping the regulation of religion but of enjoying satisfaction in and through Christ as the real Sabbath rest ([link]vv. 23-28[/link]).[br][br](5) On the Sabbath He healed a man who had a withered hand, caring not for the keeping of the Sabbath but for the health of His sheep. Thus He indicated that in God's New Testament economy it is a matter not of keeping regulations but of imparting life. For this He was hated by the Pharisees, the religionists ([link]3:1-6[/link]).[br][br]All five merciful and living ways taken by the Slave-Savior to carry out His gospel service contradicted the formal and traditional religion and were therefore abhorred by the fleshly, stubborn, and lifeless religious leaders.
Or, in the house.

verse.text: And many were [xref]a[/xref]gathered together, so that there was no longer room, not even at the door. And He spoke to them the word.
And they came, bringing to Him a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]paralytic carried by four men.
verse.note: Signifying a sinner paralyzed by sin, one who is unable to walk and move before God.

verse.text: And being unable to bring [i]him[/i] to Him because of the crowd, they [note]1[/note]removed the [xref]a[/xref]roof where He was. And when they had dug through, they lowered the [note]2[/note]mat on which the paralytic was lying.
verse.note: Their zeal in seeking the Slave-Savior's healing compelled the seekers to break through the proper barrier — a wild act. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link].
A small mattress or pad. So in [link]vv. 9[/link], [link]11[/link], and 12.

verse.text: And Jesus, seeing their [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith, said to the paralytic, [note]2[/note]Child, your [note]3[/note]sins are [xref]b[/xref]forgiven.
verse.note: Faith here, which issues from hearing the word of Christ ([link]Rom. 10:17[/link]), indicates that the seekers had heard of the Slave-Savior.
This loving word spoken by the Slave-Savior implies kindness; in this His human virtue was expressed.
Sins are the cause of sickness. The Slave-Savior's word here touched the cause of sickness so that a healing effect could come. Once the sins had been forgiven, the sickness was healed.

verse.text: But some of the [note]1[/note]scribes were sitting there and reasoning in their hearts,
verse.note: The scribes and Pharisees, as the religionists of the old and dead religion, were motivated and used by Satan, the enemy of God, to oppose, resist, and frustrate the gospel service of the Slave of God throughout His ministry ([link]vv. 16[/link], [link]24[/link]; [link]3:22[/link]; [link]7:5[/link]; [link]8:11[/link]; [link]9:14[/link]; [link]10:2[/link]; [link]11:27[/link]; [link]12:13[/link], [link]28[/link]). They thought that they were worshipping God and were zealous for Him, not knowing that the very God of their forefathers — Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob — was immediately in front of them in the form of a Slave who desired to serve them. Blinded by their traditional religion from seeing Him in the divine economy, they plotted to kill Him ([link]3:6[/link]; [link]11:18[/link]; [link]14:1[/link]); and they actually did kill Him ([link]8:31[/link]; [link]10:33[/link]; [link]14:43[/link], [link]53[/link]; [link]15:1[/link], [link]31[/link]).

verse.text: Why is this [i]man[/i] speaking this way? He is [xref]a[/xref]blaspheming! Who can forgive [xref]b[/xref]sins except One, [note]1[/note]God?
verse.note: The reasoning scribes, who considered themselves to be according to the Scriptures and theology, acknowledged the Slave-Savior merely as a man, even a despised Nazarene ([link]John 1:45-46[/link]), not realizing that the One who forgave the sins of the paralytic was the very forgiving God incarnated in the form of a lowly man (see note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link]), who came as a Slave to serve them with His salvation.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately Jesus, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]knowing fully in His spirit that they were reasoning this way within themselves, said to them, Why are you reasoning about these things in your hearts?
verse.note: The Slave-Savior knew the seekers' faith, the sick one's sins ([link]v. 5[/link]), and the scribes' inward reasoning; this indicates that He was omniscient. Such omniscience, which manifested His divine attribute, unveiled His deity, showing that He is the omniscient God. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

verse.text: Which is [note]1[/note]easier: to say to the paralytic, Your sins are forgiven, or to say, Rise and take up your mat and walk?
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link].

verse.text: But that you may know that the [xref]a[/xref]Son of [note]1[/note]Man has authority to forgive sins on earth — He said to the paralytic,
verse.note: The Slave-Savior was the very God incarnated. As such, He did not consider being equal with God a treasure to be grasped. Outwardly, He was in the likeness and fashion of man, even in the form of a slave, but inwardly, He was God ([link]Phil. 2:6-7[/link]). He was the Slave-Savior, and the God-Savior as well. Hence, He had not only the ability to save sinners but also the authority to forgive their sins. In this incident, although He as God forgave people's sins, He asserted that He was the Son of Man. This indicates that He was the true God and a real man, possessing deity and humanity. In Him men could see both His divine attributes and His human virtues.

verse.text: To you I say, [note]1[/note]Rise, [xref]a[/xref]take up your mat and go to your house.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link]. This was the healing of the paralytic. See note [link book="Mark"]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And he [note]1[/note]rose and immediately [note]2[/note]took up the mat and [note]3[/note]went out before [i]them[/i] all, so that they were all [xref]a[/xref]amazed and [xref]b[/xref]glorified God, saying, We have never seen [i]anything[/i] like this!
verse.note: This is the fulfillment of the Slave-Savior's word, "Rise, take up your mat." It was easier to say, "Your sins are forgiven," than to say, "Rise and take up your mat and walk." Since the latter word was fulfilled, surely the former also, the easier one, had been fulfilled. This is strong evidence that the Slave-Savior has authority to forgive sins on earth.
See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link].
See note [link]6[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link].

verse.text: And He went out again beside the [xref]a[/xref]sea. And all the [xref]b[/xref]crowd came to Him, and He [note]1[/note]taught them.
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And as He passed by, He saw Levi the [i]son[/i] of Alphaeus sitting at the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]tax office, and He said to him, Follow Me. And he rose and [note]3[/note]followed Him.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 14-17[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 9:9-13[/link].

A tollhouse, where taxes for the Romans were collected. Matthew was one of the tax collectors ([link]Matt. 10:3[/link]), probably in a high position. Tax collectors were condemned, despised, and abhorred by the Jews ([link]Luke 18:11[/link]; [link]Matt. 5:46[/link] and note 2). Yet Matthew was called by the Slave-Savior and was later chosen and appointed as one of the twelve apostles ([link]3:18[/link]). What mercy!
As an answer to the Slave-Savior's call, this action implied that he was abandoning his dirty job and his sinful life.

verse.text: And as He reclined [i]at table[/i] in his house, many [xref]a[/xref]tax collectors and sinners were reclining together with Jesus and His disciples, for there were many, and they were following Him.
And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]scribes of the Pharisees, seeing that He ate with sinners and tax collectors, said to His disciples, Why does He eat with tax collectors and sinners?
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link]. The scribes were self-righteous in condemning the Slave-Savior for His feasting with tax collectors and sinners.

verse.text: And when Jesus heard [i]this,[/i] He said to them, Those who are strong have no need of a [note]1[/note]physician, but those who are ill; I did not [xref]a[/xref]come to call the [xref]b[/xref]righteous, but [note]2[/note]sinners.
verse.note: This indicates that the Slave-Savior considered Himself a Physician to the people who were sick with sins.
This indicates that the Slave-Savior, as the Savior of sinners, came to save only sinners.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And the [xref]a[/xref]disciples of John and the Pharisees were [xref]b[/xref]fasting. And they came and [xref]c[/xref]said to Him, [xref]d[/xref]Why do the disciples of John and the disciples of the Pharisees fast, but Your disciples do not fast?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 18-22[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 9:14-17[/link].

verse.text: And Jesus said to them, The sons of the bridechamber cannot fast while the [xref]a[/xref]bridegroom is with them, can they? For as long a time as they have the bridegroom with them they cannot fast.
But [xref]a[/xref]days will come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them, and then they will fast in that day.
No one sews a patch of unfulled cloth on an old garment; otherwise, that which fills it up pulls away from it, the new from the old, and a worse tear is made.

And no one puts new wine into [xref]a[/xref]old wineskins; otherwise, the wine will burst the wineskins, and the wine is ruined as well as the wineskins; but new wine [i]is put[/i] into fresh wineskins.
[note]1[/note]And He [xref]a[/xref]passed through the grainfields on the [xref]b[/xref]Sabbath, and His disciples began to go [i]along,[/i] picking the [xref]c[/xref]ears of grain.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 23-28[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 12:1-8[/link].

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]Pharisees said to Him, Look! Why are they doing on the [xref]a[/xref]Sabbath what is [xref]b[/xref]not lawful?
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And He said to them, Have you [xref]a[/xref]never read what [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]David did when he had need and became hungry, he and those with him;
verse.note: Implying that the Slave-Savior is the real David, the King of the coming kingdom of God.

verse.text: How he entered into the house of God during the time of [xref]a[/xref]Abiathar the high priest and ate the [xref]b[/xref]bread of the Presence, which is not lawful [i]for anyone[/i] to [xref]c[/xref]eat except the priests, and he gave also to those who were with him?
And He said to them, The [xref]a[/xref]Sabbath came into being for man, and [note]1[/note]not man for the [xref]b[/xref]Sabbath.
verse.note: Man was not created for the Sabbath; rather, the Sabbath was ordained for man that he might enjoy it with God ([link]Gen. 2:2-3[/link]).

verse.text: So then the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man is [note]1[/note]Lord even of the Sabbath.
verse.note: This shows the Slave-Savior's deity in His humanity. He, the Son of Man, was the very God who had ordained the Sabbath, and He had the right to change what He had ordained concerning the Sabbath.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He entered again into the synagogue; and there was a [xref]a[/xref]man there who had a withered hand.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-6[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 12:9-14[/link].

verse.text: And they were [xref]a[/xref]watching Him closely [i]to see[/i] if He would heal him on the [xref]b[/xref]Sabbath, so that they might [xref]c[/xref]accuse Him.
And He said to the man who had the withered hand, Rise [i]and stand[/i] in the midst.
And He said to them, Is it [xref]a[/xref]lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do evil, to [note]1[/note]save [note]2[/note]life or to kill? But they remained silent.
verse.note: This implied that the Slave-Savior was the Emancipator, who set the suffering one free from the bondage of religious ritual.
Lit., soul.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]looking around at them with [note]1[/note]anger and being greatly grieved with the [xref]b[/xref]hardness of their heart, He said to the man, [xref]c[/xref]Stretch out your hand. And he stretched [i]it[/i] out, and his hand was [note]2[/note]restored.
verse.note: Toward the opposers the Savior's anger was exercised, and He was greatly grieved at their hardness; but toward the sick His compassion was exercised, and He restored the withered member. His anger and grief may be considered the expression of the genuineness of His humanity, whereas His compassion and healing were a merging of His human virtue with His divine power, which were manifested simultaneously to men. Thus, His deity in His humanity was again expressed before men. See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].
See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. The restoration of the withered hand displayed the power of the Slave-Savior's deity.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]Pharisees went out and [xref]a[/xref]immediately took [xref]b[/xref]counsel with the [xref]c[/xref]Herodians against Him [i]as to[/i] how they might [xref]d[/xref]destroy Him.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And Jesus withdrew with His disciples to the [xref]a[/xref]sea, and a great multitude from Galilee [xref]b[/xref]followed; and from Judea
And from Jerusalem and from Idumea and beyond the Jordan and around [xref]a[/xref]Tyre and Sidon, a great [xref]b[/xref]multitude, hearing what things He did, came to Him.
And He told His disciples to have a little [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]boat ready near Him because of the crowd, so that they would not [xref]b[/xref]throng Him;
verse.note: The Slave-Savior needed first the sea ([link]v. 7[/link]) and then a little boat to escape the pressing of the crowd, indicating that the crowd's thronging Him was a frustration to His gospel service.

verse.text: For He [note]1[/note]healed many, so that as many as had [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]afflictions [note]3[/note]pressed toward Him to [xref]b[/xref]touch Him.
verse.note: See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
Lit., scourges. A metaphor for afflictions, calamities.
Lit., fell upon.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]unclean spirits, when they beheld Him, fell before Him and [xref]b[/xref]cried out, saying, You are the [xref]c[/xref]Son of God!
And He [note]1[/note]charged them many times [xref]a[/xref]not to make Him known.
verse.note: The demons' crying out concerning the Slave-Savior was a further frustration to His gospel service. He charged them not to make Him known.

verse.text: And He went up to the mountain and [xref]a[/xref]called to [i]Him[/i] those whom He Himself wanted, and they went to Him.
And He [note]1[/note]appointed [note]2[/note]twelve, [note]3[/note]whom He also named apostles, so that they might be with Him and that He might send them to [note]4[/note]preach
verse.note: This was for the spreading of the Slave-Savior's gospel service.
See note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 21[/link].
Some MSS omit, whom He also named apostles.
See note [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And to have the [xref]a[/xref]authority to [note]1[/note]cast out the demons.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. To preach ([link]v. 14[/link]) the gospel was to minister God to people; to cast out demons was to keep Satan away from people. These constituted the main purpose of the Slave-Savior's gospel service.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He appointed the [xref]a[/xref]twelve: and to Simon He [note]2[/note]gave the name [xref]b[/xref]Peter;
verse.note: For [link]vv. 16-19[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 10:2-4[/link].
Lit., placed on, or, put on. So in [link]v. 17[/link].

verse.text: And James the [i]son[/i] of [xref]a[/xref]Zebedee, and [xref]b[/xref]John the brother of James, and He gave them the name, [note]1[/note]Boanerges, that is, Sons of Thunder;
verse.note: Greek from Aramaic. A name added to James and John because of their impetuosity (cf. [link]Luke 9:54-55[/link]; [link]Mark 9:38[/link] and note).

verse.text: And Andrew, and Philip, and Bartholomew, and [xref]a[/xref]Matthew, and Thomas, and James the [i]son[/i] of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus, and Simon the Cananaean,
And [xref]a[/xref]Judas Iscariot, who also [note]1[/note]betrayed Him.
verse.note: Lit., delivered Him up. So throughout the book.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]He came into a [xref]a[/xref]house, and again a crowd came together, so that they could [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]not even eat bread.
verse.note: Some MSS read, they came.
This indicates the busyness, diligence, and faithfulness of the Slave-Savior as the Slave of God in His evangelistic service.

verse.text: And when His [xref]a[/xref]relatives heard about [i]it,[/i] they went out to lay hold of Him, for they said, [note]1[/note]He is [xref]b[/xref]beside Himself.
verse.note: "He is beside Himself" was an exclamation expressing the natural concern for the Slave-Savior on the part of His relatives. It opened the way for the scribes to blaspheme Him ([link]v. 22[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And the [note]2[/note]scribes who came down from [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem [xref]b[/xref]said, He [xref]c[/xref]has [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]Beelzebul, and by the [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]ruler of the demons He casts out the demons.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 22-30[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 12:24-32[/link].
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
This was a word of blasphemy ushered in by the exclamation of natural concern in [link]v. 21[/link].

The Slave-Savior cast out demons, the evil workers for the dark kingdom of Satan, yet the opposers said that He did it by the ruler of the demons. What a subtlety of the evil one, who motivated these evil opposers to say this! They were the co-workers of the evil one and even were one with him.

verse.text: And He called them to [i]Himself[/i] and said to them in parables, How can Satan cast out Satan?
And if a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom is not able to stand;
verse.note: This indicates that Satan has not only a house but also a kingdom. His house is a house of sin ([link]1 John 3:8[/link], [link]10[/link]), and his kingdom is a kingdom of darkness ([link]Col. 1:13[/link]). The sinners belong to both his house and his kingdom. The demons belong to his kingdom and possess people for his kingdom.

verse.text: And if a house is divided against itself, that house will not be able to stand;
And if Satan has risen up against himself and is divided, he is not able to stand but has come to an end.

But no one can enter into the house of the strong man and thoroughly [xref]a[/xref]plunder his [note]1[/note]goods unless he first [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]binds the strong man, and then he will thoroughly plunder his house.
verse.note: Sinners kept in Satan's house for his kingdom. The Slave-Savior bound Satan, the strong man, and entered into his house to plunder the sinners so that through regeneration they could be brought into the house of God ([link]Eph. 2:19[/link]) for the kingdom of God ([link]John 3:5[/link]).
This indicates that while the Slave-Savior was doing the gospel service, He was binding the strong man, Satan. The gospel service is a warfare to destroy Satan and his kingdom of darkness.

verse.text: Truly I say to you that all sins will be [xref]a[/xref]forgiven the sons of men, and whatever blasphemies they [xref]b[/xref]blaspheme,
But whoever blasphemes against the [note]1[/note]Holy [xref]a[/xref]Spirit has no forgiveness forever, but is guilty of an [note]2[/note]everlasting sin.
verse.note: This shows that the Slave-Savior's gospel service, especially in casting out the demons to destroy the dark kingdom of Satan, was by the Holy Spirit, with whom He was anointed and by whom He was being led continuously in His move ([link]Luke 4:18[/link], [link]1[/link]; [link]Mark 1:12[/link]).
A sin that will not be forgiven forever.

verse.text: [i]He said this[/i] because they said, He has an unclean spirit.
And [xref]a[/xref]His [note]1[/note]mother and His [xref]b[/xref]brothers came, and standing outside, [xref]c[/xref]they sent [i]word[/i] to Him and called Him.
verse.note: After the opposers' blasphemy, which was instigated by Satan, the relatives of the Slave-Savior came again to trouble Him with their natural concern for Him. Undoubtedly, this too was motivated by the evil one.

verse.text: And a crowd sat around Him, and they said to Him, Behold, Your mother and Your brothers and Your sisters are outside seeking You.
And He answered them and said, [note]1[/note]Who is My mother and My brothers?
verse.note: See note [link]48[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 12[/link]. This indicated the Slave-Savior's rejection of His relatives' natural concern. To defeat the evil one's schemes and to fulfill His gospel service, He refused to remain in any relationship in the natural life. This displayed His absoluteness for God in His humanity.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]looking around at those sitting in a circle around Him, He said, Behold, My mother and My [xref]b[/xref]brothers!
For whoever [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]does the will of God, this one is [note]2[/note]My brother and sister and mother.
verse.note: See note [link]50[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 12[/link].

Through His gospel service the Slave-Savior made the believing sinners His spiritual relatives, who became His many brothers ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:11[/link]) in the house of God ([link]Heb. 3:5[/link]) and His many members for the building up of His mystical Body ([link]Eph. 5:30[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]) to do the will of God.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And again He began to [note]2[/note]teach [xref]a[/xref]beside the [xref]b[/xref]sea, and a very great crowd was gathered unto Him, so that He stepped into a [xref]c[/xref]boat in the sea and sat down, and all the crowd was on the land, facing the sea.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-12[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 13:1-15[/link].
See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. So for [i]taught[/i] in the next verse.

verse.text: And He taught them many things in parables and said to them in His [xref]a[/xref]teaching:
Listen! Behold, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sower went out to [note]2[/note]sow.
verse.note: Signifying the Slave-Savior ([link]Matt. 13:37[/link]), who was the Son of God coming to sow Himself as the seed of life (see note [link]26[sup]3[/sup][/link]) in His word ([link]v. 14[/link]) into men's hearts that He might grow and live in them and be expressed from within them.

This sowing was the Slave-Savior's proclaiming of the gospel of God, which brought in the kingdom of God ([link]1:14-15[/link]). It was, as in [link]v. 26[/link], the sowing of the seed of life in the word ([link]v. 14[/link]) spoken by the Slave-Savior, indicating that His gospel service was to sow the divine life into the people whom He served. The growth of this life depends on the condition of the ones served, and its issue differs according to their various conditions, as portrayed in this parable.

verse.text: And as he sowed, some [i]seed[/i] fell beside the way, and the birds came and devoured it.
And other [i]seed[/i] fell on the rocky place, where it did not have much earth, and [xref]a[/xref]immediately it sprang up because it had no depth of earth.
And when the sun [xref]a[/xref]rose, it was scorched; and because it had no root, it withered.
And other [i]seed[/i] fell into the [xref]a[/xref]thorns, and the thorns came up and utterly choked it, and it yielded no fruit.
And others fell into the good earth and yielded fruit, coming up and growing; and one [xref]a[/xref]bore thirtyfold, and one sixtyfold, and one a [xref]b[/xref]hundredfold.
And He said, He who has [xref]a[/xref]ears to hear, let him hear.
And when He was [xref]a[/xref]alone, those around Him, with the twelve, asked Him about the parables.

And He said to them, To you it has been given [i]to know[/i] the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]mystery of the kingdom of God, but to those [xref]b[/xref]outside, all things [note]2[/note]are in [xref]c[/xref]parables,
verse.note: God's economy concerning His kingdom was a hidden mystery, which has been unveiled to the Slave-Savior's disciples. Yet since the nature and character of the kingdom of God are wholly divine, and the elements through which it is brought forth are the divine life and the divine light (see notes [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]26[sup]1[/sup][/link], and [link]21[sup]1[/sup][/link]), the kingdom of God, especially in its reality as the genuine church in this age ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]), is still entirely a mystery to the natural man. Divine revelation is required to understand it.
Or, are done, become.

verse.text: In order that [xref]a[/xref]seeing they may see and not perceive, and hearing they may hear and [xref]b[/xref]not understand, lest they [xref]c[/xref]turn and it be forgiven them.
And He said to them, Do you not [note]1[/note]know this [xref]a[/xref]parable? And how will you [note]1[/note]know all the parables?
verse.note: The first [i]know[/i] here denotes the inward, subjective understanding; the second denotes the outward, objective knowledge.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]sower sows the [xref]b[/xref]word.
And these are the ones beside the way, where the word is sown; and when they hear, [xref]a[/xref]immediately Satan comes and takes away the word which has been sown into them.
And likewise, these are the ones being sown on the rocky places, who, when they [xref]a[/xref]hear the word, immediately receive it with joy.
Yet they have no root in themselves, but last only [xref]a[/xref]for a time; then when affliction or persecution occurs because of the word, immediately they are [xref]b[/xref]stumbled.
And others are the ones being sown into the thorns; these are the ones who have heard the word,
And the [xref]a[/xref]anxieties of the age and the [xref]b[/xref]deceitfulness of [xref]c[/xref]riches and the lusts for other things enter in and utterly choke the word, and it becomes unfruitful.
And these are the ones sown on the good earth: [i]those[/i] who hear the word and receive [i]it[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]bear fruit, one thirtyfold, and one sixtyfold, and one a hundredfold.

And He said to them, Does the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lamp come so that it may be placed under the [note]2[/note]bushel or under the bed? [i]Does it[/i] not [i]come[/i] that it may be placed on the [note]3[/note]lampstand?
verse.note: The lamp here, which shines light, indicates that the Slave-Savior's gospel service not only sows life into the people whom He serves but also brings light to them. Hence, such a divine service issues in the believers as luminaries ([link]Phil. 2:15[/link]) and the churches as lampstands ([link]Rev. 1:20[/link]) that shine as His testimony in this dark age and consummate in the New Jerusalem, which has the outstanding characteristics of life and light ([link]Rev. 22:1-2[/link]; [link]21:11[/link], [link]23-24[/link]).
See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].
See note [link]15[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: For nothing is [xref]a[/xref]hidden except that it may be manifested, nor has [i]anything[/i] become concealed but that it may come into the open.
If anyone has [xref]a[/xref]ears to hear, let him hear.
And He said to them, Take heed what you hear. [note]1[/note]With what measure you measure, it shall be measured to you, and it shall be added to you.
verse.note: In [link]Matt. 7:2[/link] and [link]Luke 6:38[/link] this word is applied to the way we treat others. Here it is applied to the way we hear the word of the Lord. The measure that can be given to us by the Lord depends on the measure of our hearing. As much as we can hear, that much He will give.

verse.text: For he who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]has, it shall be given to him; and he who does not have, even what he has shall be taken away from him.
verse.note: The word here, as in [link]Matt. 13:10-13[/link] and [link]Luke 8:18[/link], is concerned with how we hear the word of the Lord.

verse.text: And He said, So is the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God: as if a [note]2[/note]man cast [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]seed on the earth,
verse.note: The kingdom of God is the reality of the church, which is brought forth by the resurrection life of Christ through the gospel ([link]1 Cor. 4:15[/link]). Regeneration is the entrance to the kingdom ([link]John 3:5[/link]), and the growth of the divine life within the believers is the kingdom's development ([link]2 Pet. 1:3-11[/link]). See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
The Slave-Savior as the sower. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link].

The seed of the divine life ([link]1 John 3:9[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:23[/link]) sown into the Slave-Savior's believers, indicating that the kingdom of God, which is the issue and goal of the Slave-Savior's gospel, and the church in this age ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]) are a matter of life, the life of God, which sprouts, grows, bears fruit, matures, and produces a harvest; they are not a matter of lifeless organization produced through man's wisdom and ability. The apostles' words in [link]1 Cor. 3:6-9[/link] and [link]Rev. 14:4[/link], [link]15-16[/link] confirm this.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]sleeps and rises night and day, and the seed sprouts and [note]2[/note]lengthens — how, he does not know.
verse.note: The words [i]sleeps and rises night and day[/i] and [i]how, he does not know[/i] should not be applied to the Slave-Savior. This verse illustrates the spontaneity of the growth of the seed (cf. [link]v. 28[/link]).
I.e., grows.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]earth bears fruit [note]2[/note]by itself: first a blade, then an ear, then full grain in the ear.
verse.note: I.e., the good earth ([link]v. 8[/link]), signifying the good heart that was created by God ([link]Gen. 1:31[/link]) so that His divine life can grow in man. Such a good heart works together with the seed of the divine life sown into it, allowing the seed to grow and bear fruit spontaneously for the expression of God. The word here enables us to have faith in this spontaneity. Thus, here, in contrast to [link]Matt. 13:24-30[/link], tares are not mentioned, on the negative side.
Or, spontaneously.

verse.text: But when the fruit is ripe, [xref]a[/xref]immediately he sends forth the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sickle, because the harvest has come.
verse.note: Signifying the angels sent by the Lord to reap the harvest ([link]Rev. 14:16[/link]; [link]Matt. 13:39[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He said, How shall we liken the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God, or in what parable shall we [note]2[/note]present it?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 30-32[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 13:31-32[/link].
Some MSS read, compare.

verse.text: It is like a [xref]a[/xref]mustard seed, which, when it is sown on the earth, is smaller than all the seeds on the earth.
And when it is sown, it comes up and becomes [note]1[/note]greater than all the herbs and produces great branches, so that the [note]1[/note]birds of heaven can roost under its shade.
verse.note: What is signified by the seed in [link]vv. 3[/link] and [link]26[/link] and the lamp in [link]v. 21[/link] discloses the nature and inward reality of the kingdom of God; whereas what is signified by the mustard seed's becoming great, contrary to its kind, and the birds' roosting under its shade speaks of the corruption and outward appearance of the kingdom of God.

verse.text: And in many such [note]1[/note]parables He spoke the [xref]a[/xref]word to them as they were [xref]b[/xref]able to hear;
verse.note: These parables display the Slave-Savior's divine wisdom and knowledge ([link]Matt. 13:34-35[/link]).

verse.text: And without a [xref]a[/xref]parable He did not speak to them; but [xref]b[/xref]privately to His own disciples He explained all things.
And He said to them on that day when evening had fallen, Let us [xref]a[/xref]go over to the other side.
[note]1[/note]And leaving the crowd, they took Him along, just as He was, in the [xref]a[/xref]boat; and other boats were with Him.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 36-41[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 8:23-27[/link].

verse.text: And there arose a great [xref]a[/xref]windstorm, and the waves beat into the [xref]b[/xref]boat, so that the boat was already beginning to fill up.
And He was in the stern, [note]1[/note]sleeping on the cushion. And they woke Him and said to Him, Teacher, does it not matter to You that we are perishing?
verse.note: The Slave-Savior was sleeping and resting in the boat, which was being beaten by the windstorm, while the disciples were threatened by the storm. This indicates that He was above the threatening windstorm and was not bothered by it. As long as the disciples had Him with them in their boat, they should, by faith in Him ([link]v. 40[/link]), have shared His rest and enjoyed His peace.

verse.text: And having awoken, He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rebuked the wind and said to the sea, Be silent! Be still! And the wind [xref]b[/xref]ceased and there was a [xref]c[/xref]great calm.
verse.note: While the disciples were following Him, the Slave-Savior, as a man with divine authority, controlled the storm that threatened them.

verse.text: And He said to them, Why are you [xref]a[/xref]cowardly in this way? How [i]is it that[/i] you do not have [xref]b[/xref]faith?
And they became greatly frightened and said to one another, Who then is this, that even the wind and the sea [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]obey Him?
verse.note: This not only displayed the Slave-Savior's divine authority but also testified that He was the very Creator of the universe ([link]Gen. 1:9[/link]; [link]Job 38:8-11[/link]). He is the Creator, the One who has the authority!

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And they came to the other [xref]a[/xref]side of the sea, into the region of the [xref]b[/xref]Gerasenes.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-20[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 8:28-34[/link]. In Mark the record of these events is much more detailed than in Matthew. This is strong evidence that Mark's Gospel, as a biography of the Slave of God, stresses His work instead of His word, giving more details than the other Gospels.

verse.text: And when He came out of the boat, [xref]a[/xref]immediately, from out of the tombs, a man with an [xref]b[/xref]unclean spirit met Him,
Who had his dwelling among the [note]1[/note]tombs. And no one could bind him any longer, not even with a chain,
verse.note: Tombs are places connected with death and Hades ([link]Psa. 88:3[/link], [link]5[/link]).

verse.text: Because he had often been bound with shackles and chains, and the chains had been torn apart by him, and the shackles smashed, and no one was strong enough to subdue him.
And continually night and day, among the tombs and in the mountains, he cried out and gashed himself with stones.
And when he saw Jesus from a distance, he ran and [xref]a[/xref]worshipped Him,

And crying out with a [xref]a[/xref]loud voice, [note]1[/note]he said, [note]2[/note]What do I have to do [xref]b[/xref]with You, Jesus, Son of the [xref]c[/xref]Most High God? I [xref]d[/xref]adjure You by God, do not torment me!
verse.note: This indicates that the possessed man was usurped by the unclean spirit to the extent that he was being used by the spirit as if he were the spirit himself.
Lit., What to me and to You? Some versions render it, "What do You have to do with me?"

verse.text: For He had said to him, Come out of the man, unclean [note]1[/note]spirit.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And He questioned him, What is your name? And he said to Him, [xref]a[/xref]Legion is my name, because we are many.
And he entreated Him much not to send them out of the region.
Now there on the mountainside was a great herd of hogs feeding.
And [note]1[/note]they entreated Him, saying, Send us to the hogs, so that we may enter into them.
verse.note: Some MSS read, all the demons.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]He gave them permission. And the unclean spirits came out and entered into the hogs, and the herd, about two thousand, rushed down the steep slope into the sea, and they were drowned in the sea.
verse.note: Some MSS read, immediately Jesus.

verse.text: And those who were feeding them fled and reported [i]it[/i] in the city and in the countryside. And they came to see what had happened.
And they came to Jesus and saw the demon-possessed man sitting down, clothed, and sane, the man who had had the [xref]a[/xref]legion, and they became frightened.
And those who had seen [i]it[/i] related to them how it had happened to the demon-possessed man and concerning the hogs.
And they began to entreat Him to [xref]a[/xref]depart from their borders.
And as He got into the boat, the man who had been demon-possessed begged Him that he might stay with Him.
And He did not allow him, but said to him, Go to your house, to your own [i]people,[/i] and report to them what great things the Lord has done for you, and [i]how[/i] He has had mercy on you.
And he departed and began to proclaim in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Decapolis what great things Jesus had done for him, and all marveled.
verse.note: A district of ten cities.

verse.text: And when Jesus had [xref]a[/xref]crossed over again in the boat to the other [xref]b[/xref]side, a great crowd gathered to Him, and He was beside the sea.
[note]1[/note]And [xref]a[/xref]one of the [xref]b[/xref]rulers of the synagogue came, Jairus by name, and seeing Him, fell at His feet;
verse.note: For [link]vv. 22-43[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 9:18-26[/link]. In this record of the miraculous deeds of the Slave of God in His gospel service, Mark again gives more details than Matthew. It is a vivid presentation, portraying especially the sufferings of the sick, the Slave-Savior's tenderness and kindness toward them in His saving service, and Peter's presence.

verse.text: And he entreated Him much, saying, My little daughter is at the point of death. Please come and [xref]a[/xref]lay Your hands on her that she may be [note]1[/note]healed and live.
verse.note: Lit., saved.

verse.text: And He went with him, and a great crowd followed Him and [xref]a[/xref]pressed upon Him.
And a [note]1[/note]woman [i]was there,[/i] who had a [xref]a[/xref]flow of blood for [xref]b[/xref]twelve years.
verse.note: Since this woman's case is merged with the case of the ruler's daughter, and since the twelve years of the woman's sickness are the age of the girl, and both are females, one older, one younger, these cases can be considered a complete case of one person. In this view the girl was born, so to speak, in the woman's death-sickness and died of it. When the woman's death-sickness was healed by the Savior, the dead girl rose up from death. This signifies that every fallen person is born in the death-sickness of sin and is dead in sin ([link]Eph. 2:1[/link]). When his death-sickness of sin is dealt with by the Savior's redeeming death ([link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]), he rises up out of death into life ([link]John 5:24-25[/link]).

verse.text: She had suffered much under many physicians and had spent everything she had and had not benefited at all, but rather became worse.
When she heard the things concerning Jesus, she came up in the crowd behind [i]Him[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]touched His garment,
For she said, If I touch even His garments, I will be [note]1[/note]healed.
verse.note: Or, made whole; lit., saved. Sickness is an oppression exercised over the sick by the devil. Hence, the Slave-Savior's healing was a saving service rendered to the suffering victim that she might enjoy relief and release from the evil one's oppression ([link]Acts 10:38[/link]). See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately the fountain of her blood was dried up, and she knew in her body that she was cured of the [xref]b[/xref]affliction.
And immediately Jesus, realizing in Himself that [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]power had gone out of Him, turned around in the crowd and said, Who [xref]b[/xref]touched My garments?
verse.note: The Slave-Savior was God incarnated to be a man ([link]John 1:1[/link], [link]14[/link]). His garments signify His perfect behavior in His humanity — His perfection in His human virtues. To touch His garments was actually to touch Him in His humanity, in which God was embodied ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]). By such a touch His divine power was transfused, through the perfection of His humanity, into the one who had touched Him, and it became her healing. The God who dwells in unapproachable light became touchable in the Slave-Savior through His humanity for her salvation and enjoyment. This was the service of the Slave-Savior, as the Slave of God, to the sick sinner.

verse.text: And His disciples said to Him, You see the crowd [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]pressing upon You and You say, Who touched Me?
verse.note: The pressing crowd did not receive anything from the Savior, but the one who touched Him did.

verse.text: And He looked around to see her who had done this.
But the woman, [note]1[/note]frightened and trembling, knew what had happened to her, and she came and fell down before Him and told Him the whole truth.
verse.note: Fear is inward, whereas trembling is shown outwardly.

verse.text: And He said to her, [note]1[/note]Daughter, your [xref]a[/xref]faith has [note]2[/note]healed you. Go [note]3[/note]in [xref]b[/xref]peace and be [note]4[/note]well from your affliction.
verse.note: The Slave-Savior's power in healing expressed His deity ([link]v. 30[/link] and note); His word, given with love and kindness in sympathy, expressed His humanity. In this case His deity and His humanity again were merged for His expression.
See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Lit., into.
Or, whole, sound.

verse.text: While He was still speaking, [i]some[/i] came from [i]the house of[/i] the [xref]a[/xref]ruler of the synagogue, saying, Your daughter has died. Why [xref]b[/xref]bother the Teacher any longer?
But Jesus, [note]1[/note]overhearing the word spoken, said to the ruler of the synagogue, Do not be afraid — only believe.
verse.note: Or, hearing unintentionally, ignoring. Some MSS read, hearing.

verse.text: And He did not allow anyone to accompany Him except [xref]a[/xref]Peter and James and [xref]b[/xref]John the brother of James.
And they came to the house of the ruler of the synagogue, and He saw a commotion and [i]people[/i] weeping and wailing greatly.
And He entered in and said to them, Why do you make a commotion and weep? The child has not died but is [xref]a[/xref]sleeping.
And they laughed scornfully at Him. But He, [xref]a[/xref]putting [i]them[/i] all out, took the father of the child and the mother and those with Him and went in to where the child was.
And He [xref]a[/xref]took hold of the child's hand and said to her, [note]1[/note]Talitha koum! which being interpreted is, Little girl, to you I say, [xref]b[/xref]Arise!
verse.note: Aramaic.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately the little girl rose up and walked about, for she was [xref]b[/xref]twelve years old. And immediately, they were [xref]c[/xref]amazed with great amazement.
And He strongly commanded them that [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]no one should know about this, and told [i]them[/i] to give her [i]something[/i] to eat.
verse.note: See note [link]44[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And He went out from there and [xref]a[/xref]came into His own country, and His disciples followed Him.

And when the Sabbath had come, He began to [note]1[/note]teach in the [xref]a[/xref]synagogue; and many hearing were [xref]b[/xref]astounded, saying, Where [i]did[/i] this man [i]get[/i] these things? And what is this wisdom given to this man, and [i]how is it that[/i] such works of power take place through His hands?
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. So for this verb throughout this chapter.
