verse.text: Is not this the [note]1[/note]carpenter, the son of Mary, and [xref]a[/xref]brother of James and Joses and Judas and Simon? And are not His sisters here with us? And they were [xref]b[/xref]stumbled because of Him.
verse.note: See note [link]55[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 13[/link]. The blind despisers' word here may be considered a fulfillment of the prophecy in [link]Isa. 53:2-3[/link] concerning the Slave-Savior: "Like a root out of dry ground. He has no attracting form nor majesty that we should look upon Him, nor beautiful appearance that we should desire Him. He was despised and forsaken of men." To know Him in that way was to know Him in His humanity according to the flesh ([link]2 Cor. 5:16[/link]), not in His deity according to the Spirit ([link]Rom. 1:4[/link]). In His humanity He was a root out of dry ground, a sprout from the stump of Jesse and a branch from his roots ([link]Isa. 11:1[/link]), a Shoot unto David ([link]Jer. 23:5[/link]; [link]33:15[/link]), the Shoot who was a man and the Servant of Jehovah ([link]Zech. 3:8[/link]; [link]6:12[/link]), One who came out of the seed of David according to the flesh ([link]Rom. 1:3[/link]). In His deity He was the Shoot of Jehovah for beauty and glory ([link]Isa. 4:2[/link]), the Son of God marked out in power according to the Spirit ([link]Rom. 1:4[/link]).

verse.text: And Jesus said to them, A [xref]a[/xref]prophet is not without honor except in his [i]own[/i] country and among his [i]own[/i] relatives and in his [i]own[/i] house.
And He could [note]1[/note]not do any work of power there, except to [xref]a[/xref]lay His hands upon a few [i]of the[/i] sick and [note]2[/note]heal [i]them.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]58[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 13[/link].
See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. So for this verb throughout this chapter.

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]marveled because of their unbelief; and He went around the [xref]b[/xref]villages in a circuit, teaching.
And He [xref]a[/xref]called the twelve to [i]Him[/i] and began to send them out two by two and gave them [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]authority over the unclean spirits;
verse.note: See notes [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: And He charged them not to [xref]a[/xref]take anything for the journey except only a staff: [note]1[/note]no bread, no bag, no money in their belt;
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: But [i]to have[/i] sandals tied on; and [i]said,[/i] Do not put on two [note]1[/note]tunics.
verse.note: A shirt-like undergarment. So throughout the book.

verse.text: And He said to them, Wherever you enter into a house, there remain until you [note]1[/note]depart from that place.
verse.note: Lit., go out from there.

verse.text: And whatever place does not receive you nor hear you, as you go out from there, [xref]a[/xref]shake off the dust under your feet for a testimony [note]1[/note]against them.
verse.note: Or, to.

verse.text: And they went forth and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]proclaimed that [i]men[/i] should [xref]b[/xref]repent,
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And they [note]1[/note]cast out many demons and [xref]a[/xref]anointed many [i]of the[/i] sick with oil and healed [i]them.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And King Herod [xref]a[/xref]heard [i]of it,[/i] for His name had become known, and they said, [xref]b[/xref]John the baptizer has been raised from the dead, and because of this these works of power [note]1[/note]are operating through him.
verse.note: I.e., are operating and are being manifested.

verse.text: But others said, He is [xref]a[/xref]Elijah; and others said, [i]He is[/i] a [xref]b[/xref]prophet, like one of the prophets.
But Herod, hearing [i]of it,[/i] said, He whom I [xref]a[/xref]beheaded, John, this one was raised!
For Herod himself had sent [i]men[/i] and seized John and bound him in [xref]a[/xref]prison on account of [xref]b[/xref]Herodias, the wife of Philip his brother, because he had married her.
For John had been saying to Herod, It is not lawful for you to have the wife of your [xref]a[/xref]brother.
Thus, Herodias had a grudge against him and wanted to kill him and could not,
For Herod feared [xref]a[/xref]John, knowing that he was a [xref]b[/xref]righteous and holy man, and kept him safe. And when he heard him, he was very perplexed yet [xref]c[/xref]heard him gladly.
And an opportune day came, when Herod on his [xref]a[/xref]birthday made a [xref]b[/xref]banquet for his courtiers and the commanders and the leading men of Galilee.

And when the daughter of Herodias herself entered and danced, she pleased Herod and those reclining [i]at table[/i] with [i]him.[/i] The king said to the girl, Ask of me whatever you want, and I will give [i]it[/i] to you.
And he swore to her earnestly, Whatever you ask of me, I will give to you, up to [xref]a[/xref]half of my kingdom.
And she went out and said to her mother, What should I ask for? And she said, The head of John the baptizer.
And coming in [xref]a[/xref]immediately with haste to the king, she asked, saying, I want you to give me at once the head of John the Baptist on a platter.
And the king was very grieved, yet because of the oaths and those reclining [i]at table,[/i] he did not want to refuse her.
And [xref]a[/xref]immediately the king sent a guard and ordered [i]him[/i] to bring his head. And he went out and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]beheaded him in the prison,
verse.note: This indicates Satan's hatred, expressed by the darkness and injustice of the worldly power, toward the faithful forerunner of the Slave-Savior. See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 14[/link].

verse.text: And brought his head on a platter, and gave it to the girl, and the girl gave it to her mother.
And when his [xref]a[/xref]disciples heard [i]about it,[/i] they came and took his corpse and put it in a tomb.
And the [xref]a[/xref]apostles gathered together to Jesus and [xref]b[/xref]reported to Him all that they did and [i]all[/i] that they taught.

And He said to them, Come by yourselves privately to a [xref]a[/xref]deserted place and rest a while. For there were many coming and going, and they did [note]1[/note]not even have opportunity to [xref]b[/xref]eat.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And they [xref]a[/xref]went away in the boat to a deserted place privately.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 32-44[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 14:13-21[/link].

verse.text: And many saw them going away and [xref]a[/xref]recognized [i]them,[/i] and they ran together there on foot from all the cities and got [i]there[/i] before them.

And getting out, He saw a great crowd, and He was [note]1[/note]moved with [xref]a[/xref]compassion for them because they were like sheep not having a shepherd, and He began to teach them many things.
verse.note: This exhibited the Slave-Savior's virtue in His humanity. Such virtue was carried out by the power of His deity (cf. note [link]43[sup]1[/sup][/link]). The virtue in His humanity and the power of His deity were mingled as one, showing that He is both man and God.

verse.text: And when the hour had already become late, His disciples came to Him and said, This place is deserted, and the hour is already late;
[xref]a[/xref]Send them away so that they may go into the surrounding countryside and villages and buy for themselves something to eat.

But He answered and said to them, You [xref]a[/xref]give them [i]something[/i] to eat. And they said to Him, Shall we go away and buy two hundred [note]1[/note]denarii worth of bread and give [i]it[/i] to them to eat?
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in John 6[/link].

verse.text: And He said to them, [xref]a[/xref]How many loaves do you have? Go and see. And when they found out, they said, Five, and two fish.
And He ordered them to have all recline [note]1[/note]by companies on the green grass.
verse.note: The Greek phrase denotes dividing into companies at a party. Sitting by companies was equivalent to sitting at tables. This figure implies that the Lord's feeding of the multitude with bread and fish was like the spreading of a feast to entertain guests.

verse.text: And they sat down [note]1[/note]in groups, by hundreds and by fifties.
verse.note: Lit., garden plot by garden plot. Here, the arrangement of plots in a garden refers figuratively to a group of people arranged in an orderly way. The groups of people sat down in well-ordered square plots, so that they looked like flowering plants arranged in plots in a garden. This figure implies that those who are fed by the Lord are like fragrant, beautiful flower beds ([link]S.S. 5:13[/link]; [link]6:2[/link]).

verse.text: And He took the five loaves and the two fish and, [xref]a[/xref]looking up to heaven, He [xref]b[/xref]blessed and broke the loaves and gave [i]them[/i] to the disciples to set before them; and the two fish He divided among all.
And they all ate and were satisfied.
And they took up [note]1[/note]twelve full handbaskets of the broken pieces [i]of bread[/i] and of the fish.
verse.note: This not only displayed the power of the Slave-Savior's deity as the Creator, who calls things not being as being ([link]Rom. 4:17[/link]), but also signifies the bountiful and inexhaustible supply of His divine life ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:19[/link]).

verse.text: And those who had eaten the loaves were five thousand men.

[note]1[/note]And [xref]a[/xref]immediately He [xref]b[/xref]compelled His disciples to step into the boat and [xref]c[/xref]go before to the other side, toward [xref]d[/xref]Bethsaida, while He sent the crowd away.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 45-51[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 14:22-32[/link].

verse.text: And after He said farewell to them, He went away to the [xref]a[/xref]mountain to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]pray.
verse.note: See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And when evening fell, the [xref]a[/xref]boat was in the midst of the sea and He was alone on the land.

And seeing them distressed as they rowed, for the wind was contrary to them, He came toward them about the fourth watch of the night, [note]1[/note]walking on the sea, and He intended to pass by them.
verse.note: In [link]4:38[/link] the Slave-Savior was sleeping in a boat that was being beaten by a windstorm that threatened His followers. Here, He was walking on the sea while His followers, as they rowed, were distressed by the waves of the sea. These incidents indicate that the Slave-Savior, as the Creator and Ruler of the universe ([link]Job 9:8[/link]), was not distressed by any circumstance and that He would care for His followers in their troubles while they followed Him in their journey.

verse.text: But when they saw Him walking on the sea, they thought that it was a ghost, and they cried out,

For they all saw Him and were [xref]a[/xref]startled. But [xref]b[/xref]immediately He spoke with them and said to them, Take [xref]c[/xref]courage. [note]1[/note]It is I. Do not be [xref]d[/xref]afraid.
verse.note: Lit., I am.

verse.text: And He went up unto them into the boat, and the wind [xref]a[/xref]ceased. And they were greatly [xref]b[/xref]astonished in themselves beyond measure,
For they did not [xref]a[/xref]understand concerning the loaves, but rather their heart was hardened.
And they [xref]a[/xref]crossed over to the land and came to [xref]b[/xref]Gennesaret and moored [i]there.[/i]
And when they came out of the boat, [xref]a[/xref]immediately [i]the people[/i] [xref]b[/xref]recognized Him,
And they ran about that whole region and began to carry around on [xref]a[/xref]mats those who were ill to any place where they heard that He was.

And wherever He entered into [xref]a[/xref]villages or into cities or into the countryside, they laid those who were sick in the [xref]b[/xref]marketplaces and begged Him that they might touch if even the [note]1[/note]fringe of His garment; and as many as [xref]c[/xref]touched Him were [note]2[/note]healed.
verse.note: See notes [link]20[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link] and [link book="Mark"]30[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].
Or, made whole. See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And the [xref]a[/xref]Pharisees and some of the scribes gathered together to Him when they had come from [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-23[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 15:1-20[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]had seen that some of His disciples ate bread with common hands, that is, [xref]a[/xref]unwashed.
verse.note: Some MSS read, seeing...unwashed, they found fault.

verse.text: (For the Pharisees and all the Jews, unless they [note]1[/note]carefully wash their hands, do not eat, holding the [xref]a[/xref]tradition of the [note]2[/note]elders;
verse.note: Lit., with the fist.
I.e., ancients, people of the previous generations.

verse.text: And [i]when they come[/i] from the marketplace, unless they [note]1[/note]wash themselves, they do not eat. And there are [xref]a[/xref]many other things which they have received to hold, the [xref]b[/xref]dipping of cups and pitchers and copper vessels[note]2[/note].)
verse.note: Lit., baptize. Some MSS have, sprinkle.
Some MSS add, and couches.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]Pharisees and the scribes questioned Him, Why do Your disciples not walk according to the tradition of the elders, but eat bread with common hands?
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And He said to them, Well has Isaiah prophesied concerning you [note]1[/note]hypocrites, as it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"This people honors Me with their [xref]b[/xref]lips, but their heart stays far away from Me;
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].

verse.text: But in vain do they [note]1[/note]worship Me, teaching [i]as[/i] teachings the commandments of [xref]a[/xref]men."
verse.note: Revere. The feeling of awe or devotion is stressed.

verse.text: While leaving the commandment of God, you hold the tradition of men[note]1[/note].
verse.note: Some MSS add, the dipping of pitchers and cups and many other such similar things you do.

verse.text: And He said to them, You nicely [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]set aside the commandment of God that you may keep your tradition.
verse.note: The result of the keeping of tradition is the setting aside of the commandment of God. Furthermore, tradition causes people to set aside the commandment of God "nicely"!

verse.text: For Moses said, [xref]a[/xref]"Honor your father and your mother," and, [xref]b[/xref]"He who speaks evil of father or mother, [note]1[/note]let him be put to death."
verse.note: Lit., let him decease by death. See note [link]4[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 15[/link].

verse.text: But you say: If a man says to his father or his mother, Whatever you would have been profited by me is [i]now[/i] [note]1[/note]corban (that is, a [xref]a[/xref]gift [i]to God[/i]),
verse.note: For the Hebrew word [i]qorban,[/i] meaning [i]an offering.[/i] Signifying anything offered to God.

verse.text: Allow him to no longer do anything for his father or his mother.
[i]Thus[/i] you deprive the word of God of its authority by your tradition which you have handed down. And [xref]a[/xref]many things similar to these you do.
And He called the crowd to [i]Him[/i] again and said to them, Hear Me, all [i]of you,[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]understand.
There is nothing outside of a man which entering into him can [note]1[/note]defile him, but the things coming out of a man are the things which defile a man.
verse.note: Make him common, unclean ([link]Acts 11:8[/link]). So in the succeeding verses.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear.
verse.note: Some MSS omit this verse.

verse.text: And when He entered into a [xref]a[/xref]house from the crowd, His disciples questioned Him concerning the [xref]b[/xref]parable.
And He said to them, Are you also in the same manner without [xref]a[/xref]understanding? Do you not understand that everything that enters from outside into a man is not able to defile him,
Because it does not enter into his heart, but into the [xref]a[/xref]stomach, and goes out into the drain? (In saying this, He made all foods [xref]b[/xref]clean.)
And He said, That which goes out of the man, that [xref]a[/xref]defiles the man.
For from within, out of the [xref]a[/xref]heart of men, proceed evil reasonings, fornications, thefts, [xref]b[/xref]murders,
[xref]a[/xref]Adulteries, [xref]b[/xref]covetousness, wickedness, [note]1[/note]deceit, licentiousness, [note]2[/note]envy, [xref]c[/xref]blasphemy, arrogance, foolishness.
verse.note: Or, guile.
Lit., a wicked eye. A Semitic expression referring to the eye that intends to do evil and, by extension, to hostility, jealousy, or envy.

verse.text: All these [note]1[/note]wicked things proceed from within and defile the man.
verse.note: The wicked things that proceed from within are the evil issues of man's fallen and sinful nature ([link]v. 21[/link]; [link]Rom. 7:18[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He rose up from there and [xref]a[/xref]went away into the borders of [xref]b[/xref]Tyre [note]2[/note]and Sidon. And entering into a [xref]c[/xref]house, He wanted [note]3[/note]no one to know [i]about it;[/i] yet He could not escape notice.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 24-30[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 15:21-28[/link].
Some MSS omit, and Sidon.
The Lord never wanted publicity for Himself.

verse.text: But a woman whose little daughter had an [xref]a[/xref]unclean spirit heard about Him, and [xref]b[/xref]immediately she came and fell at His feet.
Now the woman was a [xref]a[/xref]Greek, [note]1[/note]Syrophoenician by race. And she asked Him to cast the demon out of her daughter.
verse.note: Syrian by tongue, Phoenician by race (cf. [link]Acts 21:2-3[/link]). Since the Phoenicians were descendants of the Canaanites, she was a Canaanite woman ([link]Matt. 15:22[/link]). What made her a Greek — religion, marriage, or some other factor — is difficult to determine.

verse.text: And He said to her, [xref]a[/xref]First let the [xref]b[/xref]children be satisfied, for it is not good to take the children's [xref]c[/xref]bread and throw [i]it[/i] to the [note]1[/note]little [xref]d[/xref]dogs.
verse.note: Pet dogs, house dogs.

verse.text: And she answered and said to Him, Yes, Lord, [i]but[/i] even the little dogs under the [xref]a[/xref]table eat of the little children's crumbs.
And He said to her, Because of this word, [xref]a[/xref]go. The [note]1[/note]demon has gone out of your daughter.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And she went away to her house and found the little child lying on the couch and the demon gone out.

And again He [xref]a[/xref]came out of the borders of [xref]b[/xref]Tyre and came through Sidon to the Sea of [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Galilee in the midst of the borders of [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]Decapolis.
verse.note: See note [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 15[/link].
A district of ten cities.

verse.text: And they brought to Him [note]1[/note]one who was [xref]a[/xref]deaf and who [xref]b[/xref]spoke with difficulty, and they entreated Him to [xref]c[/xref]lay His hand on him.
verse.note: Signifying one who is spiritually deaf and dumb, unable to hear the voice of God and to praise Him ([link]Isa. 35:6[/link]) and speak for Him ([link]Isa. 56:10[/link]). The dumbness of such a person is due to his deafness. The Slave-Savior's healing salvation is well able to heal the deafness and dumbness of such a one, first by dealing with his ears and then by touching his tongue.

verse.text: And He took him aside from the crowd privately and [note]1[/note]put His fingers into his ears, and He [xref]a[/xref]spat and touched his tongue.
verse.note: Or, thrust. The Slave-Savior's thrusting of His fingers into the deaf one's ears signifies His dealing with his hearing organ (cf. [link]Isa. 50:4-5[/link]; [link]Job 33:14-16[/link]), and His touching of his tongue with His spittle signifies His anointing of the dumb one's speaking organ with the word that proceeds out of His mouth. This was a healing (see note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]).

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]looking up to heaven, He [xref]b[/xref]groaned and said to him, [note]1[/note]Ephphatha! that is, Be opened!
verse.note: Aramaic.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately his ears were opened, and the bond on his tongue was released and he spoke clearly.
And He charged them [note]1[/note]not to tell [xref]a[/xref]anyone. But the more He charged them, so much the more they [xref]b[/xref]proclaimed [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]44[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And they were utterly [xref]a[/xref]astounded, saying, He has done all things well; He makes both the deaf hear and the dumb speak.
[note]1[/note]In those days, since there was again a great crowd and they did not have anything to eat, He called the disciples to [i]Him[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]said to them,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-10[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 15:32-39[/link].

verse.text: I am [note]1[/note]moved with compassion for the crowd, because for three days now they have [note]1[/note]remained with Me and they do [note]1[/note]not have anything to eat.
verse.note: The Slave-Savior's virtues of compassion, sympathy, and tender care were vividly and sweetly displayed here in His humanity.

verse.text: And if I send them away to their home hungry, they will [note]1[/note]faint on the way; and some of them have [note]1[/note]come from a distance.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And His disciples answered Him, Where will anyone be able to [i]get enough to[/i] satisfy these people with bread here in [i]this[/i] desolate place?
And He asked them, How many loaves do you have? And they said, Seven.

And He charged the crowd to recline on the ground. And taking the seven loaves, He [xref]a[/xref]gave thanks and broke [i]them,[/i] and gave [i]them[/i] to His disciples to set before [i]them,[/i] and they set [i]them[/i] before the crowd.
And they had a few small fish, and having blessed them, He said that these also should be set before [i]them.[/i]
And they ate and were satisfied. And they took up the [xref]a[/xref]surplus of broken pieces, [note]1[/note]seven baskets.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]there were about four thousand [i]people.[/i] And He sent them away.
verse.note: Some MSS read, those who had eaten.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately He got into the boat with His disciples and came into the parts of [note]1[/note]Dalmanutha.
verse.note: Dalmanutha was probably a village in the districts of Magadan ([link]Matt. 15:39[/link]). It was likely a place west of the Sea of Galilee.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Pharisees came out and began to dispute with Him, seeking from Him a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]sign from heaven [i]and[/i] [xref]c[/xref]tempting Him.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 11-21[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 16:1-12[/link].
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]. So in [link]v. 15[/link].
A sign is a miracle that has some spiritual significance.

verse.text: And He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]groaned deeply in His spirit and said, Why does this generation seek a sign? Truly I tell you, [note]2[/note]No sign shall be given to this generation.
verse.note: This too is a virtue of the Lord in His humanity, showing His sentiment toward man.
Lit., If a sign shall be given. A Hebraism, as in [link]Heb. 3:11[/link].

verse.text: And leaving them, He again got into [i]a boat[/i] and went away to the other side.
And they forgot to take bread, and except for one loaf, they did not have [i]any[/i] with them in the boat.
And He charged them, saying, Watch! Beware of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]leaven of the Pharisees and the leaven of [xref]b[/xref]Herod.
verse.note: See note [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 13[/link]. The leaven of the Pharisees was their hypocrisy ([link]Luke 12:1[/link]); the leaven of Herod was his corruption and injustice in politics (see note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link]).

verse.text: And they reasoned with one another, [note]1[/note]saying, It is because we do not have bread.
verse.note: Some MSS read, that they had no bread.

verse.text: And Jesus, [xref]a[/xref]knowing [i]it,[/i] said to them, Why are you reasoning because you have no bread? Do you not yet perceive nor [xref]b[/xref]understand? Do you have your heart [xref]c[/xref]hardened?
Having eyes, do you [xref]a[/xref]not see? And having ears, do you not hear? And do you not remember?
When I broke the [xref]a[/xref]five loaves for the five thousand, how many handbaskets full of broken pieces did you take up? They said to Him, Twelve.
And when I broke the seven for the four thousand, how many baskets filled with broken pieces did you take up? And they said, [xref]a[/xref]Seven.
And He said to them, Do you not yet [xref]a[/xref]understand?
And they came to [xref]a[/xref]Bethsaida. And they brought to Him a [note]1[/note]blind man and entreated Him to touch him.
verse.note: Signifying one who has lost his inner sight, one who is blind spiritually ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:9[/link]).

verse.text: And He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]took hold of the hand of the blind man and [note]2[/note]led him forth outside the village. And He [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]spat on his eyes and [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]laid His hands on him and asked him, Do you see anything?
verse.note: The Slave-Savior's humanity was expressed here in His intimate and loving care for the needy one. See note [link]36[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

This may indicate that the Slave-Savior would not allow what He intended to do for this blind man to be seen and known by the crowd, since He charged him not even to enter into the village ([link]v. 26[/link]). Spiritually, this may indicate that the Slave-Savior wanted the blind man to have a private and intimate time with Him so that He could infuse him with the element by which his sight could be recovered. All who are spiritually blind need such a time with the Slave-Savior.

Blindness is related to darkness ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]). To see, there is the need of light. The Slave-Savior's spittle may signify the word that proceeds out of His mouth (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in John 9[/link]), a word that conveys the divine light of life to the receiver for the recovery of his sight. Such spitting by the Slave-Savior, accompanied by His laying on of hands, was much richer than His mere touch, which had been requested for the blind man by his helpers.
Indicating that the Slave-Savior identified Himself with the blind man in order to transfuse His healing element into him.

verse.text: And he looked up and said, I [note]1[/note]see men, for I see [i]them[/i] as trees, walking.
verse.note: This may illustrate a person's spiritual seeing. In the initial stage of his spiritual recovery, a person may see spiritual things as did this blind man, who saw men as trees, walking. After a further recovery, he sees all things clearly.

verse.text: Then again He laid His hands upon his eyes, and [i]the man[/i] looked intently and was [note]1[/note]restored, and he began to see all things clearly.
verse.note: See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And He sent him to his house, saying, Do [note]1[/note]not even enter into the village[note]2[/note].
verse.note: Throughout His ministry the Slave-Savior, the Slave of God, did not want publicity. See note [link]44[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. Shunning publicity was one of the virtues that He displayed. Such a virtue was sweet and lovely.
Some MSS add, nor tell it to anyone in the village.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And Jesus and His disciples went out into the villages of [xref]a[/xref]Caesarea Philippi. And on the way He questioned His disciples, saying to them, [xref]b[/xref]Who do men say that I am?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 27-29[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 16:13-16[/link].

verse.text: And they told Him, saying, [xref]a[/xref]John the Baptist; and others, [xref]b[/xref]Elijah; but others, one of the prophets.
And He questioned them, But you, who do you say that I am? Peter answered and said to Him, You are the [xref]a[/xref]Christ!
And He charged them [note]1[/note]not to tell [xref]a[/xref]anyone concerning Him.
verse.note: The Slave-Savior did not want to promote Himself.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He [xref]a[/xref]began to teach them that the [xref]b[/xref]Son of Man must suffer many things and be [xref]c[/xref]rejected by the elders and the chief priests and the scribes and be [xref]d[/xref]killed and after [xref]e[/xref]three days [xref]f[/xref]rise.
verse.note: For [link]8:31-9:1[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 16:21-28[/link].

verse.text: And He spoke this word [xref]a[/xref]openly. And Peter took Him aside and began to rebuke Him.

But turning around and looking at His disciples, He rebuked Peter and said, Get behind Me, [xref]a[/xref]Satan! For you are not setting your [xref]b[/xref]mind on the things of God, but on the things of men.
And He called the crowd to [i]Him[/i] with His disciples and said to them, If anyone wants to follow after Me, let him deny himself and take up his [xref]a[/xref]cross and follow Me.
For whoever wants to save his [xref]a[/xref]soul-life shall lose it; but whoever will lose his soul-life for My sake and the [xref]b[/xref]gospel's shall save it.
For what does it profit a man to [xref]a[/xref]gain the whole world and forfeit his soul-life?
For what could a man give in [xref]a[/xref]exchange for his soul-life?

For whoever is [xref]a[/xref]ashamed of Me and of My words in this [xref]b[/xref]adulterous and sinful generation, the Son of Man also will be ashamed of him when He [xref]c[/xref]comes in the glory of His Father with the [xref]d[/xref]holy angels.

And He said to them, Truly I say to you, there are some of those standing here who shall by no means [xref]a[/xref]taste death until they see the [xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God having come in [xref]c[/xref]power.

[note]1[/note]And after six days Jesus [xref]a[/xref]took with [i]Him[/i] [xref]b[/xref]Peter and James and John, and brought them up alone into a high mountain privately. And He was [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]transfigured before them,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 2-13[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 17:1-13[/link].
Or, transformed.

verse.text: And His garments became [xref]a[/xref]sparkling, exceedingly [xref]b[/xref]white, such as no fuller on earth could whiten [i]them.[/i]
And Elijah with Moses appeared to them, and they were conversing with Jesus.
And Peter answered and said to Jesus, [xref]a[/xref]Rabbi, it is good for us to be here; and let us make three [xref]b[/xref]tents, one for You and one for Moses and one for Elijah.
For he did [xref]a[/xref]not know what to answer, for they had become extremely frightened.
And a [xref]a[/xref]cloud appeared, overshadowing them, and a [xref]b[/xref]voice came out of the cloud: This is My Son, the [xref]c[/xref]Beloved. [xref]d[/xref]Hear Him!
And suddenly, when they looked around, they no longer saw anyone, but Jesus only with them.

And as they were [xref]a[/xref]coming down from the mountain, He ordered them [note]1[/note]not to relate to [xref]b[/xref]anyone the things which they had seen, except when the Son of Man has [xref]c[/xref]risen from the dead.
verse.note: See note [link]44[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And they kept the word, discussing among themselves what rising from the dead was.
And they asked Him, saying, Why do the scribes say that [xref]a[/xref]Elijah must come first?

And He said to them, Elijah does indeed come first and [xref]a[/xref]restore all things. And how [i]is it that[/i] it is [xref]b[/xref]written of the Son of Man that He should [xref]c[/xref]suffer many things and be [xref]d[/xref]counted as nothing?
But I tell you that [xref]a[/xref]Elijah has [note]1[/note]indeed come, and they did to him the things that they wished, even as it is written of him.
verse.note: Or, also.

verse.text: And when [note]1[/note]they came to the disciples, [note]1[/note]they saw a great crowd around them, and some [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]scribes disputing with them.
verse.note: Some MSS have, He.
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately, when all the crowd saw Him, they were [xref]b[/xref]amazed, and they ran to [i]Him[/i] and greeted Him.
And He questioned them, What are you disputing with them?
[note]1[/note]And [xref]a[/xref]one from the crowd answered Him, [xref]b[/xref]Teacher, I brought to You my son, who has a [xref]c[/xref]dumb spirit;
verse.note: For [link]vv. 17-29[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 17:14-21[/link].

verse.text: And wherever it seizes him, it [note]1[/note]throws him down, and he foams at the mouth and grinds his teeth; and he is wasting away. And I told Your disciples to [xref]a[/xref]cast it out, and they were not able.
verse.note: Or, tears him.

verse.text: And He answered them and said, [note]1[/note]O unbelieving generation! How long shall I be [xref]a[/xref]with you? How long shall I bear with you? Bring him to Me.
verse.note: This is an exclamation uttered by the Slave-Savior because of man's unbelief.

verse.text: And they brought him to Him. And when it saw Him, the spirit [xref]a[/xref]immediately [xref]b[/xref]convulsed him greatly, and falling on the earth, he rolled about, foaming at the mouth.
And He questioned his father, How long has this been happening to him? And he said, From childhood.
And it has often thrown him both into fire and into water to destroy him. But if You can [i]do[/i] anything, [note]1[/note]have compassion on us and help us.
verse.note: Or, help us, having compassion on us.

verse.text: And Jesus said to him, [note]1[/note][i]You say,[/i] If You can. All things are possible to him who [xref]a[/xref]believes.
verse.note: Or, Concerning this [lit., the] "If You can" (referring to the word spoken in the preceding verse).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Immediately, crying out, the father of the child said, I believe; [xref]b[/xref]help my unbelief!

And Jesus, seeing that a crowd was running together toward [i]them,[/i] [xref]a[/xref]rebuked the unclean spirit, saying to it, [xref]b[/xref]Dumb and deaf spirit, I order you, [note]1[/note]come out of him and enter into him no more.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And after crying out and [xref]a[/xref]convulsing [i]him[/i] terribly, it came out. And he became as though [i]he were[/i] dead so that many said that he died.
But Jesus [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]took hold of his hand and raised him, and he stood up.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: And when He entered into the [xref]a[/xref]house, His disciples questioned Him privately, Why were we not able to cast it out?
And He said to them, This kind cannot come out by any means except prayer[note]1[/note].
verse.note: Some MSS add, and fasting.

verse.text: And they went out from there and passed through [xref]a[/xref]Galilee, and He did not want anyone to know about [i]it,[/i]

For He was [xref]a[/xref]teaching His disciples. And He said to them, The Son of Man is being delivered into the hands of men, and they will [xref]b[/xref]kill Him; and when He has been killed, after three days He will rise.
But they did not [xref]a[/xref]understand this saying and were afraid to question Him.
And they came to [xref]a[/xref]Capernaum. And when He was in the house, He [xref]b[/xref]questioned them, What were you reasoning about on the way?
And they were silent, for they had argued with one another on the way about who [i]was[/i] [xref]a[/xref]greater.
And He sat down and called the twelve and said to them, If anyone wants to be first, he shall be the last of all and the servant of all.
And He took a [xref]a[/xref]little child and set him in their midst; and [note]1[/note]taking him into His arms, He said to them,
verse.note: The Slave-Savior's humanity was expressed in His tender love toward the little ones. See notes [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link] and [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: Whoever [xref]a[/xref]receives one of such little children [note]1[/note]because of My name, [note]2[/note]receives Me; and whoever receives Me, receives not Me but Him who sent Me.
verse.note: Lit., upon, or, on; i.e., on the basis of, according to.
This shows that the Slave-Savior became one with the young children.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]John said to Him, Teacher, we saw someone [xref]b[/xref]casting out demons in Your [xref]c[/xref]name, and we [note]1[/note]forbade him because he does not follow us.
verse.note: This was an impetuous act by John, the son of thunder; it was contrary to the virtue of the Slave-Savior whom he accompanied (see note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]). John's attitude was like that of Joshua in [link]Num. 11:28[/link].

verse.text: But Jesus said, Do [note]1[/note]not forbid him, for there is [xref]a[/xref]no one who will do a work of power in My name and be able soon to speak evil of Me.
verse.note: This displayed the Slave-Savior's tolerance, in the practice of the gospel service, toward those believers who were different from the ones closer to Him. In this respect the attitude of the apostle Paul in [link]Phil. 1:16-18[/link] and that of Moses in [link]Num. 11:26-29[/link], but not that of the impetuous John, are like His. It is very meaningful that this section, [link book="Mark" chapter="9"]vv. 38-50[/link], continues the previous section, [link]vv. 33-37[/link], in which the Slave-Savior taught His followers humility because they had argued with one another concerning who was greater. In that argument the two sons of thunder, James and John, probably played the leading roles (cf. [link]10:35-45[/link]). Here the same John would not tolerate a differing believer. His impetuous action was probably related to his ambition to be great. It might have been this ambition that caused his intolerance toward the different practice of other believers. This is a basic divisive factor among Christians. The Slave-Savior surely would not go along with John in this matter.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]he who is not against us is for us.
verse.note: This word does not contradict that in [link]Matt. 12:30[/link]. Both issued from the Slave-Savior's mouth and can be considered maxims. The maxim here speaks of outward conformity in practice and is in regard to people who are not against Him ([link]Mark 9:39[/link]); that in Matthew speaks of the inward unity of purpose and is in regard to people who are against Him ([link]Matt. 12:24[/link]). To maintain the inward unity, we need to practice the word in Matthew, and as to the outward conformity, we should practice the word here, tolerating believers who differ from us.

verse.text: For whoever gives [note]1[/note]you a [xref]a[/xref]cup of water to drink because [i]you bear[/i] the name that you are [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Christ's, truly I say to you that he shall by no means lose his [note]3[/note]reward.
verse.note: John behaved as one who acted upon others. The Slave-Savior's wise word here turned him and the other disciples, making them those acted upon by others. This implied that all — whether the disciples or other believers — were under the Lord's care because all were His. Whether it was their treatment of other believers or other believers' treatment of them, anything done in the Lord's name, even the giving of a cup of water, would be rewarded by Him.
This indicates that the Slave-Savior recognized that the one forbidden by John was a genuine believer belonging to Him. This should have been a lesson to John.
This reward will be given in the coming kingdom age ([link]Luke 14:14[/link]). See notes [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link] and [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in 2 Cor. 5[/link].

verse.text: And whoever stumbles one of [note]1[/note]these [xref]a[/xref]little ones who believe into Me, it is better for him if a [note]2[/note]great millstone is placed around his neck and he is thrown into the sea.
verse.note: Here the Slave-Savior turned the subject from John and the other disciples to His believers in general, all of whom He considered little ones (not related to the little children in [link]v. 37[/link]), including John, the other disciples, and the one forbidden by them. This may be considered a warning to John and the other disciples not to stumble any one of His believers who followed Him in a different way.
Lit., millstone (turned) by a donkey.

verse.text: And if your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]hand stumbles you, [note]2[/note]cut it off; it is better for you to enter into [note]3[/note]life maimed than to have two hands and go away into [note]4[/note]Gehenna, into [note]5[/note]unquenchable [xref]b[/xref]fire.
verse.note: Here the one who causes the stumbling is changed from a person to a member of the believer's fleshly body. The believers should not stumble one another, nor should they be stumbled by their own fleshly members. This indicates the preciousness of the believers in the eyes of the Slave-Savior. They should all be fully preserved for Him. All the factors that could cause the believers to stumble should be dealt with seriously.
See note [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link]. So in [link]v. 45[/link].

[i]Life[/i] here refers to eternal life, which the overcoming believers will enjoy in the coming kingdom ([link]10:30[/link]; cf. note [link]29[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 19[/link]). To enter into this enjoyment in the coming age is to enter into the coming kingdom ([link]v. 47[/link]) and participate there in the enjoyment of eternal life.
See note [link]22[sup]8[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link]. So in the succeeding verses.

In apposition to [i]Gehenna[/i] and denoting here, according to the context, a dispensational punishment of the defeated believers (such as being hurt of the second death, mentioned in [link]Rev. 2:11[/link]); it is not eternal perdition. See note [link]49[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [i]See note 44[note]1[/note].[/i]
verse.note: Some MSS insert [link]v. 44[/link], Where their worm does not die and the fire is not quenched.

verse.text: And if your foot stumbles you, cut it off; it is better for you to enter into life lame than to have two feet and be thrown into Gehenna[note]1[/note].
verse.note: Some MSS add, into unquenchable fire.

verse.text: [i]See note 46[note]1[/note].[/i]
verse.note: Some MSS insert [link]v. 46[/link], Where their worm does not die and the fire is not quenched.

verse.text: And if your [xref]a[/xref]eye stumbles you, cast it out; it is better for you to enter into the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into Gehenna,
verse.note: This is to enter into the enjoyment of eternal life in the coming age. See note [link]43[sup]3[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Where their [note]1[/note]worm does not die and the fire is not quenched.
verse.note: The word given here and in [link]vv. 44[/link] and [link]46[/link] (which were inserted in some MSS), not found in [link]Matt. 5:29-30[/link]; [link]18:8-9[/link], or in [link]Luke 12:5[/link], is quoted from [link]Isa. 66:24[/link].

verse.text: For everyone shall be [note]1[/note]salted with [note]2[/note]fire[note]3[/note].
verse.note: I.e., to kill and eliminate the germs of corruption that came in through sin, in order to preserve the sinning believers (cf. [link]Lev. 2:13[/link]; [link]Ezek. 43:24[/link]).

This is the refining fire ([link]Mal. 3:2[/link]), the purifying, purging fire, as in [link]1 Cor. 3:13[/link], [link]15[/link] (cf. [link]Isa. 33:14[/link]), which, as a dispensational punishment in the kingdom age, will purge the believers who commit sin and are unrepentant in this age (see note [link]43[sup]5[/sup][/link]). Even in this age God purges the believers through trials as if by fire ([link]1 Pet. 1:7[/link]; [link]4:12[/link], [link]17[/link]). Dispensational punishment by fire in the coming age is in the same principle as God's chastisement through sufferings as if by fire in this age.
Some MSS add, and every sacrifice shall be salted with salt.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Salt is good, but if the salt becomes [note]2[/note]unsalty, with what will you restore its saltiness? Have salt in yourselves and be at [xref]a[/xref]peace with one another.
verse.note: See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link]. The application of the word here differs from that in [link]Matt. 5:13[/link] and [link]Luke 14:34[/link]. In Matthew and Luke, salt, portraying the believers' influence on the world, is for the salting of the corrupted world; salt here, in apposition to the purging fire, is for the salting of sinning believers, even as God's chastisements are for the sinning believers in this age. Hence, the believers should have salt in themselves that they may be purified not only from sins but also from any divisive element (such as was displayed by the impetuous John in forbidding a differing brother and in arguing for greatness) and may thus be at peace with one another. Such purging salt purges the believers' speech that they may keep peace with one another ([link]Col. 4:6[/link]). The Lord's word here indicates that John's speech to the brother who differed from him had not been purged. Thus, the entire section, [link]vv. 38-50[/link], presents the Slave-Savior's teaching concerning the believers' being tolerant for the sake of unity.
See note [link]13[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: And He rose up [xref]a[/xref]from there and came into the [note]1[/note]borders of Judea and [xref]b[/xref]beyond the Jordan; and again crowds came together to Him, and as He was accustomed, again He [note]2[/note]taught them.
verse.note: The Slave-Savior ministered in His gospel service for over three years in the despised region of Galilee (see note [link]14[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 1[/link]), far from the holy temple and the holy city, the place where He had to die for the accomplishing of God's eternal plan. As the Lamb of God ([link]John 1:29[/link]), He had to be offered to God at Mount Moriah, where Abraham offered Isaac and enjoyed God's provision of a ram as a substitute for his son ([link]Gen. 22:2[/link], [link]9-14[/link]) and where the temple was built in Jerusalem ([link]2 Chron. 3:1[/link]). It had to be there that He would be delivered, according to the counsel determined by the Trinity of the Godhead ([link]Acts 2:23[/link]), to the Jewish leaders ([link]9:31[/link]; [link]10:33[/link]) and be rejected by them as the builders of God's building ([link]8:31[/link]; [link]Acts 4:11[/link]). It had to be there that He would be crucified according to the Roman form of capital punishment ([link]John 18:31-32[/link] and note; [link]19:6[/link], [link]14-15[/link]) to fulfill the type concerning the kind of death He would die ([link]Num. 21:8-9[/link]; [link]John 3:14[/link]). Moreover, according to Daniel's prophecy ([link]Dan. 9:24-26[/link]), that very year was the year that Messiah (Christ) was to be cut off (killed). Furthermore, as the Passover lamb ([link]1 Cor. 5:7[/link]), He had to be killed in the month of the Passover ([link]Exo. 12:1-11[/link]). Hence, He had to go to Jerusalem ([link]v. 33[/link]; [link]11:1[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]15[/link], [link]27[/link]; [link]John 12:12[/link]) before the Passover ([link]John 12:1[/link]; [link]Mark 14:1[/link]) that He might die there on the day of the Passover ([link]14:12-17[/link]; [link]John 18:28[/link]) at the place and the time foreordained by God.
See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And some [note]2[/note]Pharisees came and asked Him whether it was lawful for a man to [note]3[/note]divorce a wife, so as to [xref]a[/xref]tempt Him.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 2-12[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 19:3-9[/link].
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
Lit., release. So in the succeeding verses.

verse.text: And He answered and said to them, What did Moses command you?
And they said, Moses allowed [i]us[/i] to write a [xref]a[/xref]certificate of divorce and divorce [i]her.[/i]
And Jesus said to them, Because of your [xref]a[/xref]hardness of heart he wrote this commandment for you.
But from the [xref]a[/xref]beginning of creation, He [xref]b[/xref]made them male and female.
For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother [note]1[/note]and shall be [xref]a[/xref]joined to his wife;
verse.note: Some MSS omit, and shall be joined to his wife.

verse.text: And the two shall be [xref]a[/xref]one flesh. So then they are no longer two, but one flesh.
Therefore what God has [xref]a[/xref]yoked together, let man not [xref]b[/xref]separate.
And in the house the disciples questioned Him again concerning this.
And He said to them, Whoever [xref]a[/xref]divorces his wife and marries another commits [xref]b[/xref]adultery against her.
And if she [xref]a[/xref]divorces her husband and marries another, she commits adultery.
And they [xref]a[/xref]brought little children to Him so that He might touch them, but the disciples [xref]b[/xref]rebuked them.

But Jesus, seeing [i]it,[/i] was [note]1[/note]indignant and said to them, [note]2[/note]Allow the [xref]a[/xref]little children to come to Me. Do [xref]b[/xref]not forbid them, for of [note]3[/note]such is the [xref]c[/xref]kingdom of God.
verse.note: This expressed the genuineness of the Slave-Savior's humanity. See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].
The Slave-Savior's not despising or neglecting the little ones again expressed His humanity. See notes [link]21[sup]1[/sup][/link] in this chapter and [link]36[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].
See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 19[/link].

verse.text: Truly I say to you, whoever does not receive the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God like a [xref]b[/xref]little child shall by no means enter into it.
And [xref]a[/xref]taking them into His arms, He fervently blessed them, [xref]b[/xref]laying His hands on them.

[note]1[/note]And as He went out into the road, someone ran to [i]Him[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]kneeling before Him [xref]b[/xref]asked Him, Good Teacher, what shall I do that I may inherit [xref]c[/xref]eternal life?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 17-31[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 19:16-30[/link].

verse.text: And Jesus said to him, Why do you call Me good? [xref]a[/xref]No one is good except One — [xref]b[/xref]God.
You know the commandments: [xref]a[/xref]"Do not murder, do not commit adultery, do not steal, do not bear false witness, do not defraud, honor your father and mother."
And he said to Him, Teacher, all these things I have kept from my youth.

And Jesus, [xref]a[/xref]looking upon him, was [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]moved with love for him and said to him, One thing you lack: go; the things you have, [xref]c[/xref]sell and give to the poor, and you will have [xref]d[/xref]treasure in heaven; and come, [xref]e[/xref]follow Me[note]2[/note].
verse.note: This too expressed the Slave-Savior's humanity. See notes [link]14[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]49[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Some MSS add, taking up the cross.

verse.text: And at the word his countenance fell, and he went away sorrowing, for he [xref]a[/xref]had many possessions.
And Jesus, [xref]a[/xref]looking around, said to His disciples, How difficult it will [i]be[/i] for those who have [xref]b[/xref]riches to enter into the [xref]c[/xref]kingdom of God!

And the disciples were [xref]a[/xref]amazed at His words. But Jesus again answered and said to them, [xref]b[/xref]Children, how difficult it is [note]1[/note]for those who trust in riches to [xref]c[/xref]enter into the kingdom of God!
verse.note: Some MSS omit, for those who trust in riches.

verse.text: It is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.
But they were [xref]a[/xref]astonished beyond measure and said [note]1[/note]among themselves, Then who can be saved?
verse.note: Some MSS read, to Him.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Looking upon them, Jesus said, With men it is impossible, but not with God, for all things are [xref]b[/xref]possible with God.
Peter began to say to Him, Behold, we have left all and [xref]a[/xref]followed You.
Jesus said, Truly I say to you, There is no one who has left house or brothers or sisters or mother or father or children or fields for My sake and for the [xref]a[/xref]gospel's sake,

But that he shall receive a hundred [xref]a[/xref]times as much now at this time, houses and brothers and sisters and mothers and children and fields, with [xref]b[/xref]persecutions, and in the [xref]c[/xref]coming age, [xref]d[/xref]eternal [note]1[/note]life.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: But many [xref]a[/xref]first will be last, and the last first.

Now they were on the road, [xref]a[/xref]going up to [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem, and Jesus led [i]the way[/i] before them. And they were [xref]c[/xref]amazed, and those who followed were afraid. And He took the twelve aside again and began to tell them the things that were about to happen to Him:

Behold, we are going up to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be [note]1[/note]delivered to the chief priests and to the [note]2[/note]scribes. And they will condemn Him to [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]death and deliver Him to the Gentiles,
verse.note: The Slave-Savior had predicted His death and resurrection twice already ([link]8:31[/link]; [link]9:31[/link]). Since the time for His death was at hand (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link]), He went to Jerusalem willingly, even going before His followers with a speed and boldness that amazed them ([link]v. 32[/link]). This was His obedience to God unto death ([link]Phil. 2:8[/link]), according to the counsel of God ([link]Acts 2:23[/link]), for the fulfillment of God's redemptive plan ([link]Isa. 53:10[/link]). The Slave-Savior knew that through His death He would be glorified in resurrection ([link]Luke 24:25-26[/link]) and that His divine life would be released to produce many brothers for His expression ([link]John 12:23-24[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]). For the joy set before Him, He despised the shame ([link]Heb. 12:2[/link]) and volunteered to be delivered to the Satan-usurped leaders of the Jews and to be condemned by them to death. For this, God exalted Him to the heavens, seated Him at His right hand ([link]16:19[/link]; [link]Acts 2:33-35[/link]), bestowed on Him the name which is above every name ([link]Phil. 2:9-10[/link]), made Him both Lord and Christ ([link]Acts 2:36[/link]), and crowned Him with glory and honor ([link]Heb. 2:9[/link]).
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
See note [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 20[/link].

verse.text: And they will [xref]a[/xref]mock Him and [xref]b[/xref]spit at Him and [xref]c[/xref]scourge Him, and they will [xref]d[/xref]kill [i]Him.[/i] And after three days He will rise.
[note]1[/note]And James and John, the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Zebedee, came to Him, saying to Him, Teacher, we want You to do for us whatever we [xref]b[/xref]ask You.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 35-45[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 20:20-28[/link].

verse.text: And He said to them, What do you want Me to [xref]a[/xref]do for you?
And they said to Him, Grant to us to [xref]a[/xref]sit, one on Your right and one on [i]Your[/i] left, in Your [xref]b[/xref]glory.

But Jesus said to them, You do [xref]a[/xref]not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]cup which I drink, or to be baptized with the [note]1[/note]baptism with which I am baptized?
verse.note: Both the cup and the baptism refer to the Slave-Savior's death ([link]John 18:11[/link]; [link]Luke 12:50[/link]). The cup signifies that His death was the portion given to Him by God, the portion He took to redeem sinners for God. Baptism denotes that His death was ordained by God as the way for Him to pass through for the accomplishing of God's redemption for sinners. For us He willingly drank this cup and was baptized with this baptism.

verse.text: And they said to Him, We are able. And Jesus said to them, The cup which I drink you shall drink, and with the baptism with which I am baptized, you shall be baptized.
But to sit on My right or on [i]My[/i] left is not Mine to give, but [i]it is for[/i] those for whom it has been prepared.
And when the ten heard [i]this,[/i] they began to be indignant concerning James and John.

And Jesus called them to [i]Him[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]said to them, You know that those who are esteemed as rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their great ones exercise authority over them.
But it is not so among you; but whoever wants to become [xref]a[/xref]great among you shall be your servant,
And whoever wants to be first among you shall be the [xref]a[/xref]slave of all.

For even the [note]1[/note]Son of Man did not come to be served, but to [xref]a[/xref]serve and to [xref]b[/xref]give His [note]2[/note]life as a [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]ransom for [xref]d[/xref]many.
verse.note: This is the strongest expression stating that the Slave-Savior, as the Son of Man in His humanity, was a Slave of God to serve sinners even by giving His life.
Or, soul.
This indicates that even the Slave-Savior's redemption was His service rendered to sinners for God's plan.

verse.text: And they [xref]a[/xref]came to [xref]b[/xref]Jericho. And as He was going out from Jericho, as well as His disciples and a large crowd, the son of Timaeus, Bartimaeus, a [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]blind beggar, sat by the road.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: And when he heard that it was Jesus the [xref]a[/xref]Nazarene, he began to cry out and say, Jesus, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of David, have [xref]c[/xref]mercy on me!
verse.note: See note [link]30[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 20[/link].

verse.text: And many [xref]a[/xref]rebuked him so that he would be silent, but he cried out much more, Son of David, have mercy on me!
And Jesus, standing still, said, [note]1[/note]Call him [i]here.[/i] And they called the blind man, saying to him, Take courage. Rise. He is calling you.
verse.note: Although many were rebuking the pitiful, blind beggar, the Slave-Savior charged them to call him. Again, His humanity was expressed in His pity and sympathy toward the miserable people. See notes [link]51[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]21[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And throwing his garment aside, he leaped up and came to Jesus.
And Jesus answered him and said, [note]1[/note]What do you want Me to [xref]a[/xref]do for you? And the blind man said to Him, [xref]b[/xref]Rabboni, that I may receive [i]my[/i] sight!
verse.note: What open love toward the needy one! It expressed the Slave-Savior's humanity to an unimaginable extent. See note [link]49[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And Jesus said to him, Go; your [xref]a[/xref]faith has [note]1[/note]healed you. And [xref]b[/xref]immediately he received [i]his[/i] sight and followed Him on the road.
verse.note: See notes [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And when they drew near to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem, at [xref]b[/xref]Bethphage and [xref]c[/xref]Bethany, at the [xref]d[/xref]Mount of Olives, He [xref]e[/xref]sent two of His disciples,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-11[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 21:1-10[/link].

verse.text: And said to them, Go into the village opposite you, and [xref]a[/xref]immediately upon entering into it, you will [note]1[/note]find a colt tied, on which [xref]b[/xref]no man has yet sat; untie it and bring [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: The Slave-Savior's omniscience spoke forth His deity. See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And if anyone says to you, Why are you doing this? say, The Lord has need of it and will immediately send it here again.
And they went away and found a colt tied by a door, outside on the street, and they untied it.
And some of the ones standing there said to them, What are you doing untying the colt?
And they spoke to them even as Jesus had said. And they let them [i]do it.[/i]
And they brought the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]colt to Jesus and threw their [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]garments on it, and He sat on it.
verse.note: Signifying lowliness and meekness ([link]Matt. 21:5[/link] and note 2).

Signifying people's conduct and the virtues expressed in people's conduct (see [link]Isa. 64:6[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:8[/link]). The disciples put their garments on the colt for the Lord to ride on, and many spread their garments in the road for Him to pass through ([link]v. 8[/link]), signifying, on the one hand, that they revered Him and, on the other hand, that their conduct, which was an expression of their human virtues, was a seat on which He could rest and a way that He could pass through (see [link]Matt. 21:7[/link] and note 1). Our deeds and our conduct should pave the way for the Lord and serve as a seat on which He can rest.

verse.text: And many spread their garments in the road, and others [i]spread[/i] [note]1[/note]layers of [note]2[/note]branches full of [note]3[/note]tender leaves, having cut [i]them[/i] out of the fields.
verse.note: This shows not only that the branches were many and thick but also that people could walk on them securely.

The Greek word denoted primarily layers of leaves, twigs, reeds, or straw spread for people to walk on or lie on, and, by extension, branches full of tender leaves. Here the crowd spread layers of this kind of branch as a carpet on the road so that the Slave-Savior, whom they revered and loved, could walk on them as He entered the capital.
Signifying the abundance and freshness of the human life; the opposite of withering, dry leaves ([link]Psa. 1:3[/link]).

verse.text: And those who went before and those who followed cried out, Hosanna! Blessed [i]is[/i] He who comes in the [xref]a[/xref]name of the Lord!
Blessed [i]is[/i] the coming [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of our father [xref]b[/xref]David! Hosanna in the [xref]c[/xref]highest!

And He entered into [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem, into the temple; and when He had looked around at all things, since the hour was already late, He went [xref]b[/xref]out to [xref]c[/xref]Bethany with the twelve.
[note]1[/note]And on the next day, when [xref]a[/xref]they had gone out from Bethany, He became [xref]b[/xref]hungry.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 12-14[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 21:18-19[/link].

verse.text: And seeing at a distance a [xref]a[/xref]fig tree having leaves, He came [i]to see[/i] if perhaps He would find anything on it. And when He came to it, He found nothing except [xref]b[/xref]leaves, for it was not the season for figs.
And He answered and said to it, May [note]1[/note]no one eat fruit from you [note]2[/note]forever! And His disciples heard [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: In this section, [link]vv. 12-26[/link], the record of the Slave-Savior's cursing of the fig tree and the record of His cleansing of the temple were merged, indicating His dealing simultaneously with different aspects of the corrupted and rebellious nation of Israel. The fig tree was the symbol of the nation of Israel ([link]Jer. 24:2[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]8[/link]), and the temple was the center of Israel's relationship with God. As a fig tree planted by God, the nation of Israel did not bear fruit for Him, and as the center of Israel's relationship with God, the temple was filled with corruption. Hence, the Slave-Savior cursed the fruitless fig tree and cleansed the contaminated temple. Such a dealing can be considered a harbinger of the destruction foretold in [link]12:9[/link] and [link]13:2[/link].
Lit., for the age.

verse.text: And they came to Jerusalem. And He entered into the [xref]a[/xref]temple and began to [note]1[/note]cast out those who were selling and those who were buying in the temple, and He overturned the tables of the [xref]b[/xref]money changers and the seats of those who were selling the [xref]c[/xref]doves;
verse.note: In His ministry for the spreading of the gospel in Galilee in [link]1:14-10:52[/link], the Slave-Savior's work was to proclaim the gospel, teach the truth, cast out demons, and heal the sick. In that work His human virtues with His divine attributes were expressed as His qualification for and beauty in His divine service rendered to sinners for God. In His preparation in Jerusalem for His redemptive work ([link]11:15-14:42[/link]), His major work was to confront the opposing Jewish leaders, who should have been the builders of God's building ([link]12:9-10[/link]) but had actually been usurped by God's enemy, Satan, and instigated by him to plot to kill Him. In this confrontation, under their subtle and evil questioning, testing, and examining, His human dignity was expressed in His human genuineness ([link]vv. 15-18[/link]), and His divine wisdom and authority were expressed in His human conduct and perfection ([link]11:27-12:37[/link]), so that eventually His faultfinders became His quality-provers. This paved the way for Him to point out to these blind opposers that He, the Christ, the Son of David, was the Lord of David, that is, the very God ([link]12:35-37[/link]), that they might know His deity in His humanity, that is, that He was God living in man.

verse.text: And He would not let anyone carry a vessel through the temple.
And He [note]1[/note]taught and said to them, Is it not written, "My house shall be called a house of [xref]a[/xref]prayer for all the nations"? But you have made it a [xref]b[/xref]den of robbers.
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And the chief priests and the [note]1[/note]scribes heard [i]this,[/i] and they [xref]a[/xref]sought how they might destroy Him, for they feared Him, for all the crowd was [xref]b[/xref]astounded at His teaching.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]. So in [link]v. 27[/link].

verse.text: And [i]every day[/i] when evening fell, they went [xref]a[/xref]outside the city.
And as they passed by in the morning, they saw the [xref]a[/xref]fig tree [xref]b[/xref]withered from the roots.
And Peter remembered and said to Him, [xref]a[/xref]Rabbi, behold, the fig tree which You cursed has withered.
And Jesus answered and said to them, Have [xref]a[/xref]faith in God.

Truly I say to you that whoever says to this [xref]a[/xref]mountain, Be taken up and cast into the [xref]b[/xref]sea, and does not [xref]c[/xref]doubt in his heart, but believes that what he says happens, he will have it.
For this [i]reason[/i] I say to you, All things that you pray and [xref]a[/xref]ask, believe that you have received [i]them,[/i] and you will have them.

And when you [xref]a[/xref]stand praying, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]forgive, if you have [note]2[/note]anything [xref]c[/xref]against anyone, so that your [xref]d[/xref]Father who is in the heavens may also forgive you your offenses.
verse.note: Forgiving another's offense is the ground for our heavenly Father to forgive us. This is true especially in our prayer time. In a strict sense, we cannot pray with a heart that holds anything against anyone, i.e., that feels offended by anyone or is unable to forget another's offense.
Because of another's offense.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But if you do not forgive, neither will your Father who is in the heavens forgive your offenses.
verse.note: Some MSS omit this verse.

verse.text: And they came again to Jerusalem. And as He was walking in the [xref]a[/xref]temple, the chief priests and the scribes and the elders came to Him,
And said to Him, By what authority do You do these things, or who gave You this [xref]a[/xref]authority to do these things?
And Jesus said to them, I will question you about one thing; answer Me and I will tell you by what authority I do these things.
The [xref]a[/xref]baptism of John, was it from [xref]b[/xref]heaven or from men? Answer Me.
And they reasoned with one another saying, If we say, From heaven, He will say, Why then did you [xref]a[/xref]not believe him?
But should we say, From men? — they [xref]a[/xref]feared the crowd, for all held that [xref]b[/xref]John was really a [xref]c[/xref]prophet.
And they answered Jesus and said, We do [note]1[/note]not know. And Jesus said to them, [note]2[/note]Neither do I tell you by what authority I do these things.
verse.note: This was a lie.
See note [link]27[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 21[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And He began to [xref]a[/xref]speak to them in [xref]b[/xref]parables: A man planted a [xref]c[/xref]vineyard and put a hedge around [i]it[/i] and dug a vat for a [xref]d[/xref]winepress and built a tower; and he leased it out to [xref]e[/xref]vinedressers and went [xref]f[/xref]abroad.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-12[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 21:33-46[/link].

verse.text: And he sent a [xref]a[/xref]slave to the vinedressers at the [i]proper[/i] time so that from the vinedressers he might take of the fruit of the vineyard.
And they took him and [xref]a[/xref]beat [i]him[/i] and sent [i]him[/i] away empty-handed.
And again he sent to them another slave; and that one they struck on the head and dishonored.
And he sent another, and that one they [xref]a[/xref]killed; and [i]so with[/i] many others, beating some and killing others.
He had yet one, a [xref]a[/xref]beloved son; he sent him to them last, saying, They will respect my son.
But those vinedressers said to one another, This is the [xref]a[/xref]heir. Come, let us kill him, and the inheritance will be ours!
And they took [i]him[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]killed him and threw him [xref]b[/xref]out of the vineyard.
What then will the [xref]a[/xref]master of the vineyard do? He will come and [xref]b[/xref]destroy the vinedressers and will give the vineyard to [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]others.
verse.note: The Jewish leaders, as the builders of God's building, rejected the Slave-Savior, who was the stone that became the head of the corner of the building of God ([link]v. 10[/link]). Because of this, God rejected them and gave His building work to others — the church. In this Gospel this is the only direct indication regarding the church.

verse.text: Have you not even read this Scripture, "The stone which the [xref]a[/xref]builders rejected, this has become the head of the [note]1[/note]corner.
verse.note: The corner of the church as God's building ([link]Eph. 2:20[/link]). This is an indirect reference to the church.

verse.text: This was from the Lord, and it is marvelous in our eyes"?

And they [xref]a[/xref]sought to seize Him, yet they [xref]b[/xref]feared the crowd, for they perceived that [i]it was[/i] with them in view [i]that[/i] He spoke the parable. And [xref]c[/xref]leaving Him, they went away.
[note]1[/note]And they [xref]a[/xref]sent to Him some of the [note]2[/note]Pharisees and [xref]b[/xref]Herodians that they might catch Him in [i]His[/i] [xref]c[/xref]speech.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 13-17[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 22:15-22[/link].
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And they came and said to Him, Teacher, we know that You are true and [note]1[/note]do not fear anyone, for You do not regard the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]person of men, but teach the [xref]b[/xref]way of God in truth. Is it lawful to give [xref]c[/xref]tribute to [xref]d[/xref]Caesar, or not? Should we give, or should we not give?
verse.note: Lit., it does not matter to You concerning anyone.
Lit., face.

verse.text: But He, knowing their [xref]a[/xref]hypocrisy, said to them, Why do you [xref]b[/xref]tempt Me? Bring Me a denarius that I may look [i]at it.[/i]
And they brought [i]one.[/i] And He said to them, Whose is this image and inscription? And they said to Him, Caesar's.
And Jesus said to them, The things that are Caesar's [xref]a[/xref]render to Caesar, and the [xref]b[/xref]things that are God's [xref]c[/xref]to God. And they marveled greatly at Him.
[note]1[/note]And some [xref]a[/xref]Sadducees came to Him, who say that there is [xref]b[/xref]no resurrection, and they [xref]c[/xref]questioned Him, saying,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 18-27[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 22:23-33[/link].

verse.text: Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if anyone's brother dies and leaves a [xref]a[/xref]wife behind and leaves no child, his brother should take the wife and raise up seed to his brother.
There were seven brothers. And the first took a wife, and when he died, he left no seed;
And the second took her and died, leaving behind no seed; and the third similarly;
And the seven left no seed. Last of all the woman also died.
In the resurrection, when they rise, whose wife will she be? For the seven had her [i]as[/i] wife.
Jesus said to them, Is it not because of this [i]that[/i] you err, that you do [xref]a[/xref]not know the Scriptures nor the [xref]b[/xref]power of God?
For when they [xref]a[/xref]rise from the dead, they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels in the heavens.

But concerning the dead, that they are raised, have you not read in the book of Moses, [i]in the section[/i] concerning the [xref]a[/xref]bush, how God spoke to him, saying, "I am the [xref]b[/xref]God of Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob"?
He is not the God of the dead, but of the [xref]a[/xref]living. You err greatly.

And [note]1[/note]one of the [note]2[/note]scribes approached and heard them [note]3[/note]disputing; [i]and[/i] perceiving that He answered them well, he [xref]a[/xref]questioned Him, Which is the first commandment of all?
verse.note: In [link]Matt. 22:35[/link] he is called a lawyer. [i]Scribes[/i] is a wider term that includes the lawyers, who were Mosaic jurists, interpreters of the law.
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
Dead knowledge of the Scriptures causes people to dispute with the Lord. How terrible!

verse.text: Jesus answered, The first is: "Hear, Israel: the Lord our God is [xref]a[/xref]one Lord;
And you shall [xref]a[/xref]love the Lord your God from your whole heart and from your whole soul and from your whole mind and from your whole [note]1[/note]strength."
verse.note: Referring to physical strength. We love the Lord our God with all our being, that is, from our heart, through our soul, our mind, to our body.

verse.text: The second is this: "You shall [xref]a[/xref]love your neighbor as yourself." There is no other commandment greater than [note]1[/note]these.
verse.note: See note [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 22[/link]; [link]James 2:8[/link] and notes.

verse.text: And the scribe said to Him, Well [i]said,[/i] Teacher; in truth You have said that He is one and there is not another [xref]a[/xref]besides Him;

And to love Him from the whole heart and from the whole understanding and from the whole strength and to love one's neighbor as himself is much more than all the burnt [xref]a[/xref]offerings and sacrifices.
And Jesus, seeing that he answered intelligently, said to him, You are not far from the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God. And no one [xref]b[/xref]dared to question Him anymore.

[note]1[/note]And Jesus, while He was [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]teaching in the temple, answered and [xref]b[/xref]said, How [i]is it that[/i] the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]scribes say that the Christ is the son of David?
verse.note: For [link]vv. 35-37[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 22:41-45[/link].
See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
The scribes spoke according to the letter. Their speaking differed from the speaking in [link]v. 36[/link], which was in the Holy Spirit.

verse.text: David himself said in the [xref]a[/xref]Holy Spirit, "The Lord said to my Lord, [xref]b[/xref]Sit at My right hand until I put Your enemies [xref]c[/xref]underneath Your feet."
David himself calls Him Lord, and how is He [xref]a[/xref]his [note]1[/note]son? And the great crowd [xref]b[/xref]heard Him gladly.
verse.note: In the type, the passover lamb was examined for four days before it was killed ([link]Exo. 12:3-6[/link]). The Slave-Savior also, as the real Passover lamb ([link]1 Cor. 5:7[/link]), was examined for four days before He was killed. He came to Bethany six days before the Passover ([link]John 12:1[/link]; [link]Mark 11:1[/link]). On the next day He came into Jerusalem and went back to Bethany ([link]John 12:12[/link]; [link]Mark 11:11[/link]). On the third day He came to Jerusalem again ([link]11:12-15[/link]) and began to be examined according to the Jewish law by the leaders of the Jews ([link]11:27-12:37[/link]; [link]14:53-65[/link]; [link]John 18:13[/link], [link]19-24[/link]) and according to the Roman law by Pilate, the Roman governor ([link]John 18:28-19:6[/link]; see note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 15[/link]). He was examined until the day of the Passover, when He was crucified ([link]14:12[/link]; [link]John 18:28[/link]; see note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 14[/link]). This insidious and ensnaring examination, coming from many angles, took exactly four days, and He passed, proving that He was fully qualified to be the Lamb required by God for the accomplishing of His redemption, that He may pass over the sinners, both Jews and Gentiles. See notes [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 15[/link], [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 26[/link], and [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in John 18[/link].

verse.text: And in His [xref]a[/xref]teaching He [xref]b[/xref]said, Beware of the [xref]c[/xref]scribes, who like to walk around in long robes, and [i]like[/i] greetings in the marketplaces
And [xref]a[/xref]chief seats in the synagogues and [xref]b[/xref]places of honor at the dinners,
Who [xref]a[/xref]devour the widows' houses, and for a pretense make long prayers. These shall receive [xref]b[/xref]greater [note]1[/note]judgment.
verse.note: Or, punishment, condemnation.

verse.text: And He sat down opposite the [xref]a[/xref]treasury and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]watched how the crowd cast [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]money into the treasury. And many rich [i]people[/i] cast in much.
verse.note: The Slave-Savior was God living in His humanity. As such, He was concerned to observe how God's people expressed their loyalty in their offering to Him. By this kind of observation He praised the widow's loyalty to God. The Slave-Savior's observation is more penetrating than man's.
Lit., copper; referring to copper money.

verse.text: And one [xref]a[/xref]poor widow came and cast in two lepta, which is a [note]1[/note]quadrans.
verse.note: Equal to a fourth of a penny.

verse.text: And He called His disciples to [i]Him[/i] and said to them, Truly I say to you that this poor widow has cast in more than all those who were casting into the treasury,
For they all cast in out of their surplus, but she, out of her lack, has cast in all that she had, her whole [xref]a[/xref]living.
[note]1[/note]And as He was going out of the [xref]a[/xref]temple, [note]2[/note]one of His disciples said to Him, Teacher, behold, [note]3[/note]what wonderful stones and what wonderful buildings!
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-2[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:1-2[/link].
