In His preparation for His redemptive work ([link]11:15-14:42[/link]), after confronting the opposers ([link]11:15-12:37[/link]) the Slave-Savior stayed with His followers to prepare them for His death ([link]13:1-14:42[/link]), an unexpected event that would shock and disappoint them, by (1) telling them the things that would come ([link]vv. 2-37[/link]); (2) enjoying their love, expressed in a feast, and being anointed with costly, pure nard ([link]14:3-9[/link]); (3) instituting His supper ([link]1 Cor. 11:20[/link]) that they might remember Him ([link]14:12-26[/link]); and (4) warning them that they would stumble and charging them to watch and pray ([link]14:27-42[/link]). Immediately after such a preparation, He was arrested to be crucified ([link]14:43-15:28[/link]).
Or, what manner of stones...

verse.text: And Jesus said to him, Do you see these great buildings? [note]1[/note]There shall by no means be left here a [xref]a[/xref]stone upon a stone which shall not be thrown down.
verse.note: In preparing the disciples for His death, the Slave-Savior in this chapter told them first the things to come, the things that would take place in the world during the church age, from His resurrection to His coming back. Concerning the days to come, He did not leave them in darkness; rather, He told them (1) concerning the destruction of the temple, which would occur in A.D. 70 ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]); (2) concerning the plagues at the beginning of birth pangs, which would begin after His ascension and continue until the great tribulation ([link]vv. 3-8[/link]); (3) concerning the preaching of the gospel and the persecutions in the church age ([link]vv. 9-13[/link]); (4) concerning the great tribulation and His second coming, both of which will take place in the last three and a half years of this age ([link]vv. 14-27[/link]); and (5) concerning watching, praying, and awaiting the Slave-Savior throughout the church age ([link]vv. 28-37[/link]). To the Slave-Savior's suffering followers, such an enlightening word was like "a lamp shining in a dark place, until the day dawns" ([link]2 Pet. 1:19[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And as He sat on the [xref]a[/xref]Mount of Olives opposite the temple, [xref]b[/xref]Peter and [xref]c[/xref]James and John and [xref]d[/xref]Andrew [xref]e[/xref]asked Him privately,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 3-8[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:3-8[/link].

verse.text: Tell us, when will these things be? And what will be the sign [xref]a[/xref]when all these things are about to be accomplished?
And Jesus began to say to them, [xref]a[/xref]See that no one [xref]b[/xref]leads you astray.
Many will come in My [xref]a[/xref]name, saying, I am [i]the Christ![/i] and will lead many astray.
And when you hear of wars and rumors of wars, do not be [xref]a[/xref]alarmed; it must happen, but the [xref]b[/xref]end [i]is[/i] not yet.

For nation will rise up against nation, and kingdom against kingdom; there will be [xref]a[/xref]earthquakes in various places; there will be [xref]b[/xref]famines. These things are the beginning of birth pangs.

[note]1[/note]But you, take heed to yourselves. They will [xref]a[/xref]deliver you to [xref]b[/xref]sanhedrins, and in the synagogues you will be [xref]c[/xref]beaten, and before [note]2[/note]governors and [xref]d[/xref]kings you will stand for My sake, for a testimony to them.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 9-13[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 10:17-22[/link] and [link]24:9-13[/link].
The same Greek word as for [i]princes[/i] in [link]Matt. 2:6[/link].

verse.text: Yet the gospel must first be proclaimed to all the [xref]a[/xref]nations.

And when they lead you [i]away[/i] and deliver [i]you[/i] up, do not be [xref]a[/xref]anxious beforehand [i]about[/i] what you should speak[note]1[/note], but [xref]b[/xref]whatever is given to you in that hour, speak that; for it is not you who are speaking, but the Holy [xref]c[/xref]Spirit.
verse.note: Some MSS insert, nor premeditate.

verse.text: And brother will deliver up brother to death, and a [xref]a[/xref]father [i]his[/i] child; and children will rise up against [i]their[/i] parents and put them to death.
And you will be hated by all on account of My [xref]a[/xref]name. But he who has [xref]b[/xref]endured to the end, this one shall be saved.

[note]1[/note]But when you [xref]a[/xref]see the abomination of [xref]b[/xref]desolation[note]2[/note] standing [note]3[/note]where it should not (let him who reads understand), then let those in [xref]c[/xref]Judea flee to the mountains;
verse.note: For [link]vv. 14-23[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:15-26[/link].
Some MSS add, which is spoken of by Daniel the prophet.
In the Holy Place, that is, within God's temple ([link]Matt. 24:15[/link]).

verse.text: And let him who is on the [xref]a[/xref]housetop not come down, nor enter in, to take anything out of his house;
And let him who is in the field not turn back to take his garment.
But woe to those who are [xref]a[/xref]pregnant and to those who are nursing [i]babies[/i] in those days.
And pray that [note]1[/note]it may not happen in winter,
verse.note: Some MSS read, your flight.

verse.text: For those days will be [i]a time of[/i] [xref]a[/xref]tribulation such as has [xref]b[/xref]not occurred from the [xref]c[/xref]beginning of the creation which God created until now, nor shall by any means [i]ever[/i] occur.
And unless the Lord had shortened the days, no flesh would be saved; but on account of the [xref]a[/xref]chosen, whom He chose, He [xref]b[/xref]shortened the days.
And then if anyone says to you, Behold, [xref]a[/xref]here is the Christ! Behold, there! do not believe [i]it.[/i]
For false Christs and [xref]a[/xref]false prophets will arise and will [note]1[/note]show [xref]b[/xref]signs and wonders to [xref]c[/xref]deceive, if possible, the chosen.
verse.note: Lit., give.

verse.text: But you, [xref]a[/xref]beware; [note]1[/note]I have told you all things [xref]b[/xref]beforehand.
verse.note: Some MSS add, behold.

verse.text: But in those [xref]a[/xref]days, [xref]b[/xref]after that [xref]c[/xref]tribulation, the sun will be [xref]d[/xref]darkened, and the moon will not give its light,
And the stars will be [xref]a[/xref]falling out of heaven, and the powers in the heavens will be shaken.
And then they will see the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man [xref]b[/xref]coming in the clouds with great power and glory.
And then He will send the angels, and He will [xref]a[/xref]gather together His chosen from the four winds, from the end of the earth to the end of heaven.
[note]1[/note]But learn the parable from the [xref]a[/xref]fig tree: as soon as its branch has become tender and puts forth its [xref]b[/xref]leaves, you know that the summer is near.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 28-31[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 24:32-35[/link].

verse.text: So also you, when you see these things happening, know that [note]1[/note]it is near, [xref]a[/xref]at the doors.
verse.note: Referring to the restoration of the nation of Israel, signified by the summer in [link]v. 28[/link].

verse.text: Truly I say to you that this generation shall by no means pass away until all these things happen.
Heaven and earth will [xref]a[/xref]pass away, but My [xref]b[/xref]words shall by no means pass away.
But concerning that [xref]a[/xref]day or hour, no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but the [xref]b[/xref]Father.
[xref]a[/xref]Beware, be [xref]b[/xref]alert[note]1[/note]; for you do not know when the time is.
verse.note: Some MSS add, and pray.

verse.text: It is like a man who is [i]about to[/i] go [xref]a[/xref]abroad, having left his house and given to his slaves authority, to each his work, and [i]who[/i] commanded the doorkeeper to watch.
[xref]a[/xref]Watch therefore, for you do not know when the Master of the house comes, whether in the [note]1[/note]evening or at midnight or at cockcrowing or in the morning;
verse.note: [i]Evening, midnight, cockcrowing,[/i] and [i]morning[/i] are terms used for the four Roman night watches.

verse.text: Lest He come suddenly and find you [xref]a[/xref]sleeping.
And what I say to you, I say to all: [xref]a[/xref]Watch!

[note]1[/note]Now the [xref]a[/xref]Passover and the [i]Feast of[/i] [xref]b[/xref]Unleavened Bread were [xref]c[/xref]two days away. And the chief priests and the scribes were seeking a way to [xref]d[/xref]seize Him by craftiness and [xref]e[/xref]kill [i]Him,[/i]
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-2[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 26:2-5[/link].

verse.text: For they said, Not at the feast, lest there be a [xref]a[/xref]tumult by the people.

[note]1[/note]And while He was in [xref]a[/xref]Bethany in the [xref]b[/xref]house of Simon the [xref]c[/xref]leper, as He reclined [i]at table,[/i] a woman came, having an alabaster flask of ointment, of very costly pure nard, and she broke the alabaster flask and poured [i]it[/i] over His head.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 3-9[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 26:6-13[/link].

verse.text: But there were some who were indignantly commenting among themselves: Why has this waste of the ointment [note]1[/note]been made?
verse.note: Lit., occurred.

verse.text: For this ointment could have been sold for over [xref]a[/xref]three hundred [note]1[/note]denarii and given to the [xref]b[/xref]poor. And they were infuriated with her.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in John 6[/link].

verse.text: But Jesus said, Leave her alone. Why do you trouble her? She has done a noble deed on Me.
For you always have the [xref]a[/xref]poor with you, and whenever you want, you can do good for them. But you do not always have [note]1[/note]Me.
verse.note: The Lord desires that we allow Him to have the first place in all things ([link]Col. 1:18[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]She has done what she could; she has [note]2[/note]anointed My body beforehand for the [xref]a[/xref]burial.
verse.note: Lit., What she had she did.
Or, anticipated (or, taken occasion) to anoint My body for the burial.

verse.text: And truly I say to you, Wherever the gospel is [note]1[/note]proclaimed in the whole [xref]a[/xref]world, what this woman has done shall also be told as a [xref]b[/xref]memorial of her.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Judas Iscariot, one of the [xref]b[/xref]twelve, went off to the chief priests to [xref]c[/xref]deliver Him up to them.
And when they heard [i]this,[/i] they rejoiced and promised to give him [note]1[/note]money. And he sought a way to [note]2[/note]deliver Him up opportunely.
verse.note: Thirty pieces of silver ([link]Matt. 26:15[/link]), the value of a slave ([link]Exo. 21:32[/link]).
While one of the Slave-Savior's followers was expressing her love to Him to the uttermost, another was about to betray Him. One was treasuring Him, and at the same time another was delivering Him up.

verse.text: And on the first day of the [note]1[/note][i]Feast of[/i] [xref]a[/xref]Unleavened Bread, when they [note]2[/note]sacrificed the [xref]b[/xref]passover, His disciples said to Him, Where do You want us to go and prepare so that You may eat the passover?
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 26[/link].

In the Jews' calendar, which was according to their Scripture, a day began with the evening ([link]Gen. 1:5[/link]). During the evening of the last Passover day, first the Slave-Savior ate the passover feast with His disciples and instituted His supper for them ([link]vv. 12-25[/link]); then He went with the disciples to the Garden of Gethsemane at the Mount of Olives ([link]vv. 26-42[/link]). He was arrested there and brought to the high priest, where He was judged by the Sanhedrin late in the night ([link]vv. 43-72[/link]). In the morning of the same day, He was delivered to Pilate to be judged by him and was sentenced to death ([link]15:1-15[/link]). Then He was brought to Golgotha and was crucified there at 9:00 a.m., remaining on the cross until 3:00 p.m. ([link]15:16-41[/link]), for the fulfillment of the type of the Passover ([link]Exo. 12:6-11[/link]; see note [link]37[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 12[/link]).

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]sent two of His disciples and said to them, Go into the city, and a man carrying a jar of water will meet you; follow him;
And wherever he enters, say to the [note]1[/note]master of the house, The [xref]a[/xref]Teacher says, Where is My guest room, where I may eat the [xref]b[/xref]passover with My disciples?
verse.note: Or, householder.

verse.text: And he will show you a large [xref]a[/xref]upper room, furnished [i]and[/i] ready. And there prepare for us.
And the disciples went out and came into the city and found [i]it[/i] even as He had told them, and they prepared the passover.
And when [xref]a[/xref]evening fell, He came with the twelve.

And as they were reclining [i]at table[/i] and [note]1[/note]eating, Jesus said, Truly I say to you that [note]2[/note]one of you will [xref]a[/xref]betray Me, one who is [xref]b[/xref]eating with Me.
verse.note: The eating of the passover feast ([link]v. 16[/link]), not the eating of the Slave-Savior's supper, which is in [link]vv. 22-24[/link].
Judas Iscariot.

verse.text: They began to be grieved and to say to Him one by one, Surely not I? [note]1[/note]
verse.note: Some MSS add, and another, Surely not I?

verse.text: And He said to them, It will be one of the twelve, [note]1[/note]one who dips with Me in the dish.
verse.note: After being exposed, Judas left ([link]John 13:21-30[/link]) before the Slave-Savior's supper ([link]Matt. 26:20-26[/link]). He did not participate in the Slave-Savior's body and blood, because he was not a real believer in Him but a son of perdition ([link]John 17:12[/link]), considered by the Slave-Savior even a devil ([link]John 6:70-71[/link]). [link]Luke 22:21-23[/link] seems to indicate that Judas left after the Lord's supper, which is mentioned in [link]Luke 22:19-20[/link]. However, Mark's record, like Matthew's, shows that Judas was identified by the Slave-Savior as His betrayer ([link]vv. 18-21[/link]) before He instituted His supper ([link]vv. 22-24[/link]). Mark's record is according to historical sequence, whereas Luke's sequence is according to morality. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Matt. 8[/link].

verse.text: For the Son of Man is [note]1[/note]going away, even as it is [xref]a[/xref]written concerning Him, but woe to that man through whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would have been good for that man if he had not been born.
verse.note: This refers to His going to die.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And as they were [note]2[/note]eating, He took [xref]a[/xref]bread and [xref]b[/xref]blessed [i]it,[/i] and He broke [i]it[/i] and gave [i]it[/i] to them, and said, Take; this is My [xref]c[/xref]body.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 22-26[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 26:26-30[/link].

This was the eating of the Slave-Savior's supper, after He and His followers had eaten the passover feast in [link]vv. 16-18[/link]. He initiated this new feast, which was for His believers' remembrance of Him, to replace the passover feast, the old testament feast for the elect's remembrance of Jehovah's salvation ([link]Exo. 12:14[/link]; [link]13:3[/link]). This new feast of the new testament is for the remembering of the Slave-Savior through the eating of the bread, which signifies His body given for His believers ([link]1 Cor. 11:24[/link]), and the drinking of the cup, which signifies His blood shed for their sins ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]). The bread denotes life ([link]John 6:35[/link]), the life of God, the eternal life, and the cup denotes blessing ([link]1 Cor. 10:16[/link]), which is God Himself as the believers' portion ([link]Psa. 16:5[/link]). As sinners, the believers should have had the cup of God's wrath as their portion ([link]Rev. 14:10[/link]). But the Slave-Savior drank that cup for them ([link]John 18:11[/link]), and His salvation became their portion, the cup of salvation ([link]Psa. 116:13[/link]) that runs over ([link]Psa. 23:5[/link]), the content of which is God as the believers' all-inclusive blessing. Such a bread and such a cup are the constituents of the Slave-Savior's supper, which is a table ([link]1 Cor. 10:21[/link]), a feast, set up by Him that His believers may remember Him by enjoying Him as such a feast. Thus, as His believers remember Him, they display His redeeming and life-imparting death ([link]1 Cor. 11:26[/link] — His blood separated from His body declares His death), testifying to the entire universe of His rich and marvelous salvation.

verse.text: And He took a cup and gave thanks, and He gave [i]it[/i] to them; and they all drank of it.
And He said to them, This is My [xref]a[/xref]blood of the [note]1[/note]covenant, which is being poured out for [xref]b[/xref]many.
verse.note: In [link]Exo. 24:3-8[/link] God made a covenant with redeemed Israel ([link]Heb. 9:18-21[/link]), which became the old testament, as a base from which He could deal with His redeemed people in the dispensation of law. The Slave-Savior came to accomplish God's eternal redemption for God's chosen people by His death, according to God's will ([link]Heb. 10:7[/link], [link]9-10[/link]), and with His blood He instituted a new covenant, a better covenant ([link]Heb. 8:6-13[/link]), which after His resurrection became the new testament ([link]Heb. 9:16-17[/link]), as a base from which God can be one with His redeemed and regenerated people in the dispensation of grace. This new covenant replaced the old covenant and at the same time changed God's old dispensation to His new dispensation. The Slave-Savior wanted His followers to know this and to live a life based on this and according to this after His resurrection.

verse.text: Truly I say to you, I shall by no means drink of the [note]1[/note]product of the vine anymore until that day when I drink it new in the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God.
verse.note: This refers to the juice of the grape.

verse.text: And after [xref]a[/xref]singing a hymn, they went out to the [xref]b[/xref]Mount of Olives.
And Jesus said to them, You will all be [xref]a[/xref]stumbled[note]1[/note], because it is written, "I will smite the Shepherd, and the sheep will be [xref]b[/xref]scattered."
verse.note: Some MSS add, because of Me this night.

verse.text: But after I have been raised, I will go before you into [xref]a[/xref]Galilee.
But Peter said to Him, Even if all will be stumbled, yet I will not!
And Jesus said to him, Truly I say to you that today in this night, before a [xref]a[/xref]rooster crows twice, you will [note]1[/note]deny Me three times.
verse.note: The verb (a compound) in Greek means [i]utterly deny.[/i] So in [link]vv. 31[/link] and [link]72[/link].

verse.text: But he went on speaking more intensely, [i]Even[/i] if I must [xref]a[/xref]die with You, I will by no means deny You! And they all said similarly.
[note]1[/note]And they came to a place named Gethsemane, and He [xref]a[/xref]said to His disciples, Sit here while I pray.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 32-42[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 26:36-46[/link].

verse.text: And He took [xref]a[/xref]Peter and James and John with Him and began to be [note]1[/note]awestruck and deeply distressed.
verse.note: "Being in the grip of a shuddering horror in the face of the dreadful prospect before Him" (Cranfield).

verse.text: And He said to them, My soul is exceedingly [xref]a[/xref]sorrowful, even to death. Remain here and [xref]b[/xref]watch.
And going forward a little, He fell on the ground and [xref]a[/xref]prayed that, if it were possible, the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]hour would pass from Him.
verse.note: The Slave-Savior's sorrow and His prayer here are the same as in [link]John 12:27[/link]. There He said that He had come for this hour; that is, He knew that the Father's will was that He should die on the cross for the fulfillment of God's eternal plan.

verse.text: And He said, [xref]a[/xref]Abba Father, all things are [xref]b[/xref]possible to You; remove this [xref]c[/xref]cup from Me; yet not what I [xref]d[/xref]will, but what [note]1[/note]You [i]will.[/i]
verse.note: The Triune God determined in His divine plan in eternity past that the Second of the Divine Trinity should be incarnated and die on the cross to accomplish His eternal redemption for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose ([link]Eph. 1:7-9[/link]). Hence, before the foundation of the world, that is, in eternity past ([link]1 Pet. 1:19-20[/link]), the Second of the Divine Trinity was ordained to be the Lamb of God ([link]John 1:29[/link]); and in the eyes of God He was slain as the Lamb of God from the foundation of the world, that is, from the creation of God's creatures, who became fallen ([link]Rev. 13:8[/link]). From the time of man's fall, lambs, sheep, calves, and bulls were used as types for God's chosen people ([link]Gen. 3:21[/link]; [link]4:4[/link]; [link]8:20[/link]; [link]22:13[/link]; [link]Exo. 12:3-8[/link]; [link]Lev. 1:2[/link]), pointing to Him who was to come as the real Lamb foreordained by God. In the fullness of time the Triune God sent the Second of the Divine Trinity, the Son of God, to come in incarnation to take a human body ([link]Heb. 10:5[/link]) that He might be offered to God on the cross ([link]Heb. 9:14[/link]; [link]10:12[/link]) to do the will of the Triune God ([link]Heb. 10:7[/link]), that is, to replace the sacrifices and offerings, which were types, with Himself in His humanity as the unique sacrifice and offering for the sanctification of God's chosen people ([link]Heb. 10:9-10[/link]). In His prayer here, immediately before His crucifixion, He prepared Himself to take the cup of the cross ([link]Matt. 26:39[/link], [link]42[/link]), being willing to do this unique will of the Father for the accomplishing of the eternal plan of the Triune God.

verse.text: And He came and found them sleeping. And He said to Peter, Simon, are you sleeping? Were you not able to watch for one hour?
[xref]a[/xref]Watch and [xref]b[/xref]pray that you may not come into [xref]c[/xref]temptation. The [xref]d[/xref]spirit is willing, but the [xref]e[/xref]flesh is weak.
And going away again, He prayed, saying the same thing.
And coming again, He found them sleeping, for their eyes were very heavy. And they did [xref]a[/xref]not know what to answer Him.

And He came the third time and said to them, Are you still sleeping and resting? It is enough. The [xref]a[/xref]hour has come; behold, the Son of Man is being [xref]b[/xref]delivered into the hands of sinners.
Arise, let us be going. Behold, the one betraying Me has drawn near.

And [xref]a[/xref]immediately, while He was still [xref]b[/xref]speaking, [xref]c[/xref]Judas, one of the twelve, appeared, and with him a crowd with swords and clubs, from the chief priests and the scribes and the elders.
Now the one who was [xref]a[/xref]betraying Him had given them a signal, saying, Whomever I kiss, He is the one. Seize Him and lead [i]Him[/i] away securely.
And when he came, he [xref]a[/xref]immediately approached Him and said, [xref]b[/xref]Rabbi! and [xref]c[/xref]kissed Him affectionately.
And they laid hands on Him and [xref]a[/xref]seized Him.
But a certain [note]1[/note]one of those standing by drew his [xref]a[/xref]sword and struck the slave of the high priest, and took off his ear.
verse.note: This was Peter ([link]John 18:10[/link], [link]26[/link]).

verse.text: And Jesus answered and said to them, Have you come out as against a robber with swords and clubs to arrest Me?
Day after day I was with you in the [note]1[/note]temple [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]teaching and you did not seize Me. But may the [xref]b[/xref]Scriptures be [xref]c[/xref]fulfilled.
verse.note: The God-forsaking and God-offending opposers, afraid of the people who warmly welcomed the Slave-Savior ([link]11:7-11[/link]) and were gladdened by His speaking ([link]12:37[/link]), dared not arrest Him in the daytime or in a public place such as the temple. Instead, they arrested Him subtly, deep in the night ([link]v. 1[/link]), as though arresting a robber ([link]v. 48[/link]).
See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And they all [xref]a[/xref]left Him and fled.
And a certain young man was accompanying Him, clothed with a linen cloth over [i]his[/i] naked body; and they seized him.
But he left the linen cloth behind and fled naked.
[note]1[/note]And they [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]led Jesus away to the high priest, and all the chief priests and the elders and the scribes came together.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 53-65[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 26:57-68[/link].
The Slave-Savior was arrested as a robber ([link]v. 48[/link]) and brought to the slaughter as a lamb ([link]Isa. 53:7[/link]).

verse.text: And Peter [xref]a[/xref]followed Him at a distance until [i]he was[/i] within the [xref]b[/xref]courtyard of the high priest. And he was [i]there[/i] sitting with the [xref]c[/xref]attendants and warming himself in the light [i]of the fire.[/i]
Now the chief priests and the whole [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sanhedrin were seeking testimony against Jesus in order to put Him to death, and they could not find [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]6[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: For many gave [xref]a[/xref]false testimony against Him, yet the testimonies were not consistent.
And [xref]a[/xref]some stood up and testified falsely against Him, saying,
We heard Him say, I will [xref]a[/xref]destroy this temple made with [xref]b[/xref]hands, and [note]1[/note]in three days I will build another made without hands.
verse.note: Lit., through.

verse.text: And neither in this regard was their testimony consistent.
And the high priest stood up in the midst and questioned Jesus, saying, Do You not answer anything? What [i]is this that[/i] these testify against You?

But He was silent and did not answer [xref]a[/xref]anything. Again the high priest questioned Him and said to Him, Are [xref]b[/xref]You the [xref]c[/xref]Christ, the Son of the [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]Blessed?
verse.note: The befuddled high priest of the traditional, God-forsaking and God-forsaken religion called God "the Blessed" in order to show how much he revered and honored God.

verse.text: And Jesus said, [note]1[/note]I am. And you shall see the [xref]a[/xref]Son of Man sitting at the [xref]b[/xref]right hand of Power and coming with the clouds of heaven.
verse.note: Concerning His behavior the Slave-Savior would not answer His faultfinders' false accusation, yet concerning His divine person, His deity, He was not silent but answered strongly and definitely, affirming His deity in His humanity by stating that as the Son of Man He would sit at the right hand of God.

verse.text: And the high priest, [xref]a[/xref]tearing his [note]1[/note]garments, said, What further need do we have of witnesses?
verse.note: Lit., tunics. Because the Greek word is plural, [i]garments[/i] is a more suitable rendering here.

verse.text: You heard the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blasphemy! How does it appear to you? And they all condemned Him as being worthy of [xref]b[/xref]death.
verse.note: The blind opposers condemned the Slave-Savior for being blasphemous in affirming His deity, not realizing that actually it was they who were blaspheming God, who was the very One whom they were slandering and mocking at that moment.

verse.text: And some began to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spit at Him and to [xref]b[/xref]blindfold His face and to [xref]c[/xref]beat Him with their fists and to say to Him, [note]2[/note]Prophesy! And the attendants, [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]slapping [i]Him[/i] about, took Him.
verse.note: This was the Jews' despising and rejecting of the Slave-Savior to the uttermost, as prophesied in [link]Isa. 53:3[/link].
This was a mocking and ridiculing word.
Lit., with slaps, took Him.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And while Peter was below in the [xref]a[/xref]courtyard, one of the servant girls of the high priest came,
verse.note: For [link]vv. 66-72[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 26:69-75[/link].

verse.text: And seeing Peter warming himself, she looked at him and said, You also were with the [xref]a[/xref]Nazarene, Jesus.
But he denied [i]it,[/i] saying, I neither know nor understand what you are talking about. And he went outside into the forecourt, and a rooster crowed.
And the servant girl, seeing him, began again to say to those standing by, This man is [i]one[/i] of them!
But again he denied [i]it.[/i] And after a little while, those standing by again said to Peter, Surely you are [i]one[/i] of them, for you are a [xref]a[/xref]Galilean as well[note]1[/note].
verse.note: Some MSS add, and your speech is similar.

verse.text: But he began to [note]1[/note]curse and to swear, I do not know this man of whom you speak!
verse.note: I.e., to put himself under a curse.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]immediately a [xref]b[/xref]rooster crowed a second time. And Peter remembered the word, how Jesus had said to him, Before a rooster crows twice, you will deny Me three times. And thinking upon it, he wept.

And [xref]a[/xref]immediately in the morning the [xref]b[/xref]chief priests held a [xref]c[/xref]consultation with the elders and scribes and the whole [note]1[/note]Sanhedrin, and having bound Jesus, they led [i]Him[/i] away and [xref]d[/xref]delivered [i]Him[/i] to [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]Pilate.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]6[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link]. Under God's sovereignty the Slave-Savior was judged not only by the Jewish leaders, in [link book="Mark"]14:53-65[/link], like a sheep before the shearers ([link]Isa. 53:7[/link]), but also by the Roman governor, in [link]vv. 1-15[/link], as a criminal before the accusers ([link]14:64[/link]), that He might die to serve sinners with His life as a ransom ([link]10:45[/link]) not only for the Jews, represented by the Jewish leaders, but also for the Gentiles, represented by the Roman governor. See note [link]37[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link].

verse.text: And Pilate [xref]a[/xref]questioned Him, Are You the [xref]b[/xref]King of the Jews? And answering him, He said, It is as you say.
And the chief priests [xref]a[/xref]accused Him of many things.
And Pilate again questioned Him, saying, Do You answer nothing? See how many things they are accusing You of.
But Jesus made [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]no further answer, so that Pilate marveled.
verse.note: The Slave-Savior would not vindicate Himself.

verse.text: Now at the [xref]a[/xref]feasts he released to them one prisoner whom they requested.
And there was one named Barabbas, bound with the [xref]a[/xref]insurrectionists who had committed [xref]b[/xref]murder in the insurrection.
And the crowd [note]1[/note]came up and began to ask [i]him to do[/i] even as he had been accustomed to do for them.
verse.note: Some MSS read, cried out.

verse.text: But Pilate answered them, saying, Do you want me to release to you the [xref]a[/xref]King of the Jews?
For he knew that [i]it was[/i] because of envy [i]that[/i] the chief priests had delivered Him up.
But the chief priests stirred up the crowd that instead he should [xref]a[/xref]release Barabbas to them.
And Pilate again answered and said to them, What then do you want me to do with Him whom you call the King of the Jews?
And again they cried out, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Crucify Him!
verse.note: This was an unreasonable cry.

verse.text: But Pilate said to them, Why, what evil has He done? But they cried out the more, Crucify Him!
And Pilate, wishing to satisfy the crowd, released to them Barabbas and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]scourged Jesus and delivered [i]Him[/i] up to be [note]2[/note]crucified.
verse.note: This exposed to the uttermost the darkness and injustice of man's politics. It was a fulfillment of the prophecy in [link]Isa. 53:5[/link], [link]8[/link], concerning the Slave-Savior's suffering.
See note [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And the [xref]a[/xref]soldiers led Him away within the courtyard, that is, the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]praetorium, and called together the whole [xref]c[/xref]cohort.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 16-20[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 27:27-31[/link].
The official residence of the governor.

verse.text: And they clothed Him in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]purple and wove a [xref]b[/xref]thorny crown and put it [note]2[/note]around His [i]head.[/i]
verse.note: Signifying royalty. The purple robe was used here in a mocking way ([link]v. 20[/link]).
Or, upon Him.

verse.text: And they began to salute Him: [note]1[/note]Rejoice, [xref]a[/xref]King of the Jews!
verse.note: See note [link]29[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: And they beat His head with a reed and [xref]a[/xref]spat at Him. And kneeling down, they bowed before Him.
And when they had [xref]a[/xref]mocked Him, they stripped Him of the purple and put His garments on Him. And they [xref]b[/xref]led Him out to crucify Him.
[note]1[/note]And they [xref]a[/xref]compelled a certain passerby coming from the country, [xref]b[/xref]Simon a Cyrenian, the father of Alexander and [xref]c[/xref]Rufus, to take up His cross.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 21-38[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 27:32-51[/link].

verse.text: And they brought Him to the place Golgotha, which is interpreted, the [xref]a[/xref]Place of a Skull.
And they [note]1[/note]tried to give Him wine mixed with [xref]a[/xref]myrrh, but He did not take [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: Or, offered Him wine.

verse.text: And they crucified Him and divided His garments, casting [xref]a[/xref]lots for them [i]to see[/i] what each should take.
Now it was the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]third hour and they crucified Him.
And there was an inscription of the charge against Him inscribed: THE [xref]a[/xref]KING OF THE JEWS.
And with Him they crucified two robbers, one on His right and one on His left.
[note]1[/note]And the Scripture was fulfilled which says, [xref]a[/xref]"And He was counted with the lawless."
verse.note: Most important MSS omit this verse.

verse.text: And those who were passing by [xref]a[/xref]blasphemed Him, [xref]b[/xref]wagging their heads and saying, [xref]c[/xref]Aha! [note]1[/note]You who [xref]d[/xref]destroy the temple and build [i]it[/i] in three days,
verse.note: This was a twisting of the Slave-Savior's word, "Destroy this temple," in [link]John 2:19[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Save Yourself and come down from the cross!
verse.note: If He had saved Himself, He could not save us.

verse.text: Likewise also the chief priests with the scribes [xref]a[/xref]mocked [i]Him[/i] with one another and said, He saved others; [xref]b[/xref]Himself He cannot save.
Let the Christ, the [xref]a[/xref]King of Israel, come down now from the cross that we may see and believe. Those who were crucified with Him also [xref]b[/xref]reproached Him.
And when the [note]1[/note]sixth hour came, [xref]a[/xref]darkness fell over the whole land until the [note]2[/note]ninth hour.
verse.note: I.e., 12:00 noon.
I.e., 3:00 p.m. So in the next verse.

verse.text: And at the ninth hour Jesus [xref]a[/xref]cried with a [xref]b[/xref]loud voice, [note]1[/note]Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani? which is interpreted, [xref]c[/xref]My God, My God, why have You forsaken Me?
verse.note: Aramaic.

verse.text: And some of those standing by heard [i]this[/i] and said, Behold, He is calling for Elijah.

And someone ran and filled a sponge with [xref]a[/xref]vinegar, and putting [i]it[/i] on a reed, gave [i]it[/i] to Him to drink, saying, Let [i]Him[/i] be. Let us see if Elijah is coming to take Him down.
And Jesus let out a [xref]a[/xref]loud cry and expired.
And the [xref]a[/xref]veil of the temple was split in two from top to bottom.
And the [xref]a[/xref]centurion standing by opposite Him, seeing that He expired in this way, said, Truly this man was the [xref]b[/xref]Son of God.

And there were also some women looking on from a distance, among whom were Mary the [xref]a[/xref]Magdalene, and [note]1[/note]Mary the [i]mother[/i] of the [note]2[/note]younger James and of Joses, and [note]3[/note]Salome,
verse.note: The mother of the Slave-Savior ([link]Matt. 13:55[/link]).
Or, smaller. The Greek word refers to either age or stature.
The wife of Zebedee and mother of James and John ([link]Matt. 27:56[/link]).

verse.text: Who, when He was in Galilee, followed Him and [xref]a[/xref]ministered to Him, as well as many other women who came up with Him to Jerusalem.
And when [note]1[/note]evening had fallen, since it was [i]the day of[/i] [xref]a[/xref]preparation, that is, the [i]day[/i] before the Sabbath,
verse.note: See note [link]38[sup]1[/sup] in John 19[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Joseph, [note]1[/note]the honorable member of the Council, from Arimathea, who was also himself [xref]b[/xref]awaiting the [xref]c[/xref]kingdom of God, came; and gathering courage, he went in to [xref]d[/xref]Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.
verse.note: The definite article indicates a man well known.

verse.text: And Pilate marveled that He had already died, and calling to [i]him[/i] the [xref]a[/xref]centurion, he questioned him whether He had been dead long.
And when he found out from the centurion, he granted the corpse to Joseph.

And [i]Joseph[/i] purchased a piece of fine linen, took Him down, and wrapped [i]Him[/i] in the fine linen. And he [note]1[/note]laid Him in a [xref]a[/xref]tomb which was hewn out of rock and rolled a stone against the [xref]b[/xref]door of the tomb.
verse.note: This was for the fulfillment of [link]Isa. 53:9a[/link].

verse.text: And Mary the [xref]a[/xref]Magdalene and Mary the [i]mother[/i] of Joses saw where He was laid.

[note]1[/note]And when the [xref]a[/xref]Sabbath was past, Mary the [xref]b[/xref]Magdalene, and [note]2[/note]Mary the [i]mother[/i] of James, and [note]3[/note]Salome bought [xref]c[/xref]spices so that they might come and [note]4[/note]anoint Him.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-8[/link], see notes in [link]Matt. 28:1-8[/link].
See note [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].
See note [link]40[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].

Different from [i]anointed[/i] in [link]Luke 4:18[/link] and [i]anointing[/i] in [link]1 John 2:20[/link]. [i]Bought spices so that they might...anoint[/i] signifies love, appreciation, and remembrance.

verse.text: And very early on the first day of the week, they came to the [xref]a[/xref]tomb as the sun rose.
And they said to one another, Who will roll away the stone for us from the door of the tomb?
And when they looked up, they saw that the [xref]a[/xref]stone had been rolled away, for it was extremely large.
And when they entered into the tomb, they saw [xref]a[/xref]a young man sitting on the right, clothed in a white robe, and they were [xref]b[/xref]alarmed.

And he said to them, Do not be alarmed. You are seeking Jesus the [xref]a[/xref]Nazarene, who has been crucified. He has been [note]1[/note]raised; He is not here. Behold the place where they laid Him.
verse.note: The Slave-Savior's resurrection is proof that God is satisfied with what He accomplished through His death (see note [link]25[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 4[/link]); it is also a confirmation of the effectiveness of His redeeming and life-imparting death ([link]Acts 2:24[/link]; [link]3:15[/link]). His resurrection became the evidence of our justification ([link]Rom. 4:25[/link]) and the power by which we could be freed from sin ([link]1 Cor. 15:17[/link]).

verse.text: But go, tell His disciples [note]1[/note]and Peter that He is going before you into [xref]a[/xref]Galilee. There you will see Him, even as He told you.
verse.note: In the angel's message to the three sisters who discovered the resurrection of the Slave-Savior, the phrase [i]and Peter[/i] is inserted only in Mark's record. This is probably due to Peter's influence on the contents of this Gospel. In any case, this phrase indicates that Peter's intimate relationship with the Slave-Savior was particular, so that it was stressed even by the angel.

verse.text: And they went out and fled from the tomb, for trembling and astonishment had seized them. And they said nothing to anyone, for they were afraid.

[note]1[/note]Now after He had risen early on the first day of the week, He [xref]a[/xref]appeared first to Mary the [xref]b[/xref]Magdalene, from whom He had [note]2[/note]cast out [xref]c[/xref]seven demons.
verse.note: Many ancient MSS omit [link]vv. 9-20[/link].
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. So in [link]v. 17[/link].

verse.text: She went and [xref]a[/xref]reported to those who had been with Him, [i]who were[/i] mourning and [xref]b[/xref]weeping.
And when they heard that He was alive and had been seen by her, they did [xref]a[/xref]not believe.
And after these things, He [xref]a[/xref]appeared in a different form to [xref]b[/xref]two of them as they were walking on their way into the countryside.
And they went away and reported to the rest, but they did not believe them either.

And afterward He [xref]a[/xref]appeared to the eleven as they were reclining [i]at table,[/i] and He reproached their unbelief and [xref]b[/xref]hardness of heart, because they did [xref]c[/xref]not believe those who had seen Him after He had risen.
And He said to them, Go into all the [xref]a[/xref]world and [note]1[/note]proclaim the gospel to [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]all the creation.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

This reveals that God's redemption, accomplished by the Slave-Savior through His death and resurrection, is not only for man, the leading one in God's creation, but also for all the creation. Hence, all things, whether on earth or in the heavens, were reconciled to God, and the gospel should be proclaimed to (in) all creation under heaven ([link]Col. 1:20[/link], [link]23[/link]). Based on this, all the creation expects to be freed from the slavery of corruption into the freedom of the glory of the children of God ([link]Rom. 8:19-22[/link]).

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]believes and is [xref]b[/xref]baptized shall be [xref]c[/xref]saved, but he who does [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]not believe shall be condemned.
verse.note: To believe (see note [link]15[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]) is to receive the Slave-Savior ([link]John 1:12[/link]) not only for forgiveness of sins ([link]Acts 10:43[/link]) but also for regeneration ([link]1 Pet. 1:21[/link], [link]23[/link]). Those who thus believe become the children of God ([link]John 1:12-13[/link]) and the members of Christ ([link]Eph. 5:30[/link]) in an organic union with the Triune God ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]). To be baptized is to affirm this by being buried to terminate the old creation through the death of the Slave-Savior and by being raised up to be the new creation of God through the Slave-Savior's resurrection. Such a baptism is much more advanced than the baptism of repentance preached by John ([link]1:4[/link]; [link]Acts 19:3-5[/link]). To believe and to be so baptized are two parts of one complete step for receiving the full salvation of God. To be baptized without believing is merely an empty ritual; to believe without being baptized is to be saved only inwardly without an outward affirmation of the inward salvation. These two should go together. Moreover, water baptism should be accompanied by Spirit baptism, even as the children of Israel were baptized in the sea (water) and in the cloud (the Spirit) — [link]1 Cor. 10:2[/link]; [link]12:13[/link].

Here the verse does not say, "He who does not believe and is not baptized." This indicates that condemnation is related only to not believing; it is not related to not being baptized. Believing, by itself, is sufficient in order to receive salvation from condemnation; yet for the completion of one's inward salvation, believing needs baptism as an outward affirmation.

verse.text: And these signs will accompany those who believe: in My [xref]a[/xref]name they will cast out demons; they will [note]1[/note]speak with new [xref]b[/xref]tongues;
verse.note: Speaking with new tongues is only one of the five signs that accompany saved believers. It is not the unique sign, contrary to what is stressed by some believers. According to the divine revelation in the Acts and the Epistles, what the Lord said here does not mean that every saved believer should have all five signs. It means that each saved believer may have some of these signs but will not necessarily have all.

verse.text: They will pick up [xref]a[/xref]serpents; and if they drink anything deadly, it shall by no means harm them; they will [xref]b[/xref]lay hands on the sick, and they will be [xref]c[/xref]well.
So then the Lord Jesus, after speaking to them, was [note]1[/note]taken up into [xref]a[/xref]heaven and sat at the [xref]b[/xref]right hand of God.
verse.note: The Slave-Savior's ascension for His exaltation by God was a sign of God's acceptance of all He had done for God's eternal plan according to God's New Testament economy ([link]Acts 2:33-36[/link]). In this exaltation God crowned Him with glory and honor ([link]Heb. 2:9[/link]), bestowed on Him the name that is above all names ([link]Phil. 2:9[/link]), and made Him the Lord of all ([link]Acts 2:36[/link]) and the Head over all things ([link]Eph. 1:22[/link]) that He may have all authority in heaven and on earth ([link]Matt. 28:18[/link]) to rule over the heavens, the earth, and the nations so that they can work together for the universal spreading of His gospel service.

verse.text: And they went out and [note]1[/note]preached everywhere, the Lord working with [i]them[/i] and confirming the word by the accompanying [xref]a[/xref]signs.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. This preaching of God's gospel to all the creation ([link]v. 15[/link]) by the resurrected and ascended Slave-Savior, the Slave of God, through His believers began from Jerusalem and has been proceeding to the uttermost part of the earth ([link]Acts 1:8[/link]) continuously and universally through the past centuries, and will continue to proceed until He comes to set up the kingdom of God on earth ([link]Luke 19:12[/link]; [link]Dan. 7:13-14[/link]).
